(Chief Negotiator) |parties = *{{flag|United Kingdom}} *{{flag|European Union}} | condition_effective = [[Ratification]] by all members of the Council of the European Union and the [[European Parliament]], the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] and the legislatures of all EU member states. | footnotes = {{reflist|group=lower-alpha}} | wikisource = Draft Agreement on the Withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union }} {{United Kingdom in the European Union}} {{multiple image | total_width = 250 | image1 = Olly Robbins.jpg |width1=1554 |caption1={{flagicon|UK}} [[Oliver Robbins]] | alt1 = | image2 = Barnier, Michel-9568.jpg |width2=2088 |height2=3137 |caption2={{flagicon|EU}} [[Michel Barnier]] | alt2 = | footer = Lead negotiators for the UK and EU }} The '''Brexit negotiations''' are taking place between the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[European Union]] for the [[Brexit|withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union]] following the [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|United Kingdom European Union membership referendum]] in June 2016. The negotiating period began on 29 March 2017 when the United Kingdom [[United Kingdom invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|served the withdrawal notice under Article 50]] of the [[Treaty on European Union]]. The period for negotiation stated in [[Withdrawal Agreement|Article 50]] is two years from notification, unless an extension is agreed. On 19 June 2017, the British [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union|Brexit Secretary]], [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]], arrived in Brussels to begin the process with [[Michel Barnier]], the Chief Negotiator appointed by the European Commission.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2017/jun/19/boris-johnson-and-gove-both-back-may-as-tory-leadership-speculation-continues-politics-live |title=UK appears to capitulate on sequencing on first day of Brexit talks – as it happened |first=Andrew |last=Sparrow |date=19 June 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=23 June 2017}} Negotiations on the [[United Kingdom European Union Withdrawal Agreement|withdrawal agreement]] (which includes a transitional period and an outline of the objectives for a future relationship between the UK and the EU) have now been concluded, with the European Union indicating that no further negotiation or changes before the UK legally leaves the EU on 29 March 2019 will be possible. If the withdrawal agreement is ratified by the UK and other EU state governments and comes into force, future negotiation might also need to address Free Trade Agreement treaties between the European Union and its members (including the UK) for one part and third countries for the other part, and the [[tariff-rate quota]], which might be split or renegotiated.{{cite web |url=https://www.ceps.eu/publications/impact-brexit-eu%E2%80%99s-international-agreements |title=The Impact of Brexit on the EU's International Agreements |date=15 July 2016 |website=Centre for European Policy Studies |accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite journal |url=https://www.cigionline.org/publications/brexit-and-international-trade-one-year-after-referendum |title=Brexit and International Trade: One Year after the Referendum |first=Valerie |last=Hughes |date=26 September 2017 |journal=Centre for International Governance Innovation |accessdate=3 April 2018}} ==Background== {{Brexit sidebar}} ===2015 United Kingdom General Election=== In the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]]'s manifesto for the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|United Kingdom General Election in May 2015]], an EU referendum was promised by the end of 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/election-2015-32302062|title=At-a-glance: Conservative manifesto|date=15 April 2015|accessdate=22 September 2018|website=Bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/apr/14/conservatives-election-manifesto-2015-the-key-points|title=Conservatives election manifesto 2015 - the key points|first=Frances|last=Perraudin|date=14 April 2015|website=the Guardian|accessdate=22 September 2018}} ==Preparatory work, and intentions== According to the European parliament, "For the moment, it appears that the two sides have different views on the sequencing and scope of the negotiations, and notably the cross-over between the withdrawal agreement and the structure of future relations, and this divergence itself may be one of the first major challenges to overcome."{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2017/599352/EPRS_IDA%282017%29599352_EN.pdf |title=UK withdrawal from the European Union |website=European Parliament |date=March 2017}} === UK negotiation === * [[Theresa May]], [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] * [[Oliver Robbins]], Europe advisor to the Prime Minister * [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]] (until 9 July 2018), [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union]]. * [[Dominic Raab]] (from 9 July 2018 until 15 November 2018), [[Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union]]. * Sir [[Tim Barrow]], [[List of Permanent Representatives of the United Kingdom to the European Union|UK Permanent Representative to the EU]] The [[Department for Exiting the European Union]] is responsible for overseeing the negotiations to leave the EU and for establishing the future relationship between the UK and EU. The United Kingdom's proposed principles were set out in the Article 50 notification: * Constructive discussions * Citizens first * Comprehensive agreement * Minimise disruption * Ireland/Northern Ireland position * Technical talks on detailed policy * Work together on European values{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/29/article-50-brexit-letter-read-full/ |title= Article 50 letter: Read it in full |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=30 March 2017}} The Prime Minister's formal letter of notification was delivered in Brussels on 29 March 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/604079/Prime_Ministers_letter_to_European_Council_President_Donald_Tusk.pdf |title=Prime Minister's letter to Donald Tusk triggering Article 50 |date=19 March 2017 |website=UK Government |access-date=1 April 2017}} It included withdrawal from the [[European Atomic Energy Community]]. The letter recognized that consequences for the UK of leaving the EU included loss of influence over the rules that affect the European economy, and UK companies trading within the EU aligning with rules agreed by institutions of which the UK would no longer be part. It proposed agreeing to seven principles for the conduct of the withdrawal negotiation. These are for: # engaging with one another constructively and respectfully, in a spirit of sincere cooperation. # aiming to strike an early agreement about the rights of the many EU citizens living in the United Kingdom, and UK citizens living elsewhere in the European Union. # working towards securing a comprehensive agreement, taking in both economic and security cooperation, and agreeing the terms of our future partnership alongside those of our withdrawal from the EU. # working together to minimise disruption and giving as much certainty as possible, letting people and businesses in the UK and the EU benefit from implementation periods to adjust in an orderly way to new arrangements. # in particular, paying attention to the UK's unique relationship with the Republic of Ireland and the importance of the peace process in Northern Ireland. # beginning technical talks on detailed policy areas as soon as possible, including a Free Trade Agreement covering sectors crucial to our linked economies such as financial services and network industries. # continuing to work together to advance and protect our shared liberal, democratic values of Europe, to ensure that Europe remains able to lead in the world, projecting its values and defending itself from security threats. ==== Role of the countries of the United Kingdom ==== {{further|Countries of the United Kingdom}} The constitutional lawyer and retired German Supreme Court judge [[Udo Di Fabio]] has stated his opinion that separate negotiations with the EU institutions by Scotland or Northern Ireland would constitute a violation of the Lisbon Treaty, according to which the integrity of a member country is explicitly put under protection.{{cite news |url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/brexit/zukunft-der-europaeischen-union-kopf-hoch-14327446.html |title=Future of the European Union – Chin up! |last=Di Fabio |first=Udo |date=7 July 2016|newspaper=[[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung]] |accessdate=29 October 2016}} ==== UK general election ==== The start of negotiations was delayed until after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|United Kingdom general election]], which took place on 8 June 2017.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39643804 |title=General election 2017: MPs back plans for 8 June poll |website=BBC News |date=19 April 2017}} [[Antonio Tajani]], speaking on 20 April said that the early election should bring stability to the UK, which would have been good for negotiations.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/general-election-is-good-for-brexit-negotiations-says-european-parliament-president-10844115 |title=General Election is good for Brexit negotiations, says European Parliament President |website=Sky News |date=20 April 2017}} In the event, the election led to a [[hung parliament]] which has reduced the Prime Minister's room for manoeuvre; in particular in respect of the [[Irish border question]] due to her dependency on a [[confidence and supply]] agreement with Northern Ireland's [[Democratic Unionist Party]]. === EU27 negotiation === {{see also|European Union negotiating directives for Brexit}} * [[Michel Barnier]], Chief negotiator * [[Guy Verhofstadt]], representative of the [[European Parliament]] in the negotiations * [[Donald Tusk]], [[President of the European Council]] * [[Antonio Tajani]], [[President of the European Parliament]] * [[Jean-Claude Juncker]], [[President of the European Commission]] Following the United Kingdom's notification under Article 50, draft guidelines for the negotiations were sent to EU delegations of the 27 other member states (the EU27). The draft, prepared by the [[President of the European Council]], states that the guidelines define the framework for negotiations under Article 50 and set out the overall positions and principles that the Union will pursue throughout the negotiation. It states that in the negotiations the Union's overall objective will be to preserve its interests, those of its Member States, its citizens and its businesses, and that, in the best interest of both sides, the Union will be constructive throughout and strive to find an agreement. The draft sets out two Core Principles: # The European Council will continue to base itself on the principles set out in the statement of Heads of State or Government and of the Presidents of the European Council and the European Commission on 29 June 2016. It reiterates its wish to have the United Kingdom as a close partner in the future. It further reiterates that any agreement with the United Kingdom will have to be based on a balance of rights and obligations, and ensure a level-playing field. Preserving the integrity of the [[European Single Market]] excludes participation based on a sector-by-sector approach. A non-member of the Union, that does not live up to the same obligations as a member, cannot have the same rights and enjoy the same benefits as a member. In this context, the European Council welcomes the recognition by the British Government that the four freedoms of the Single Market are indivisible and that there can be no "cherry picking". " # Negotiations under Article 50 TEU ([[Treaty on European Union]]) will be conducted as a single package. In accordance with the principle that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed, individual items cannot be settled separately. The Union will approach the negotiations with unified positions, and will engage with the United Kingdom exclusively through the channels set out in these guidelines and in the negotiating directives. So as not to undercut the position of the Union, there will be no separate negotiations between individual Member States and the United Kingdom on matters pertaining to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the Union."{{cite news |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |title=In full: The EU's draft guidelines for Brexit negotiations |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/03/31/full-eus-draft-guidelines-brexit-negotiations/ |date=31 March 2017 |accessdate=8 April 2018 }} According to the European Parliament, the withdrawal agreement and any possible transitional arrangement(s) should enter into force "well before the elections to the European Parliament of May 2019", and the negotiations should focus on:{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/resources/library/media/20170329RES69090/20170329RES69090.pdf |title=European Parliament resolution on negotiations with the United Kingdom following its notification that it intends to withdraw from the European Union |website=European Parliament |date=29 March 2017}} * The legal status of European Union citizens living or having lived in the United Kingdom and of United Kingdom citizens living or having lived in other Member States, as well as other provisions concerning their rights; * The settlement of financial obligations between the United Kingdom and the European Union; * The European Union's external border; * The clarification of the status of the United Kingdom's international commitments taken as a Member of the European Union, given that the European Union of 27 Member States will be the legal successor of the European Union of 28 Member States; * Legal certainty for legal entities, including companies; * The designation of the Court of Justice of the European Union as the competent authority for the interpretation and enforcement of the withdrawal agreement. On 18 April 2017, a spokesman for [[Donald Tusk]] said "We expect to have the Brexit guidelines adopted by the European Council on 29 April and, following that, the Brexit negotiating directives ready on 22 May".{{Cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/election-call-likened-to-hitchcock-film-by-eus-donald-tusk-10842357 |title=Election call likened to Hitchcock film by EU's Donald Tusk |last=Minelle |first=Bethany |date=18 April 2017 |website=Sky News |access-date=19 April 2017}} On 29 April the EU27 unanimously endorsed the draft guidelines with no debate.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/eu-leaders-unanimously-agree-brexit-strategy-10855627 |title=EU leaders unanimously agree Brexit strategy |website=Sky News |date=29 April 2017}} In a speech to a plenary session of the European Committee of the Regions in Brussels on 22 March 2017, Barnier, as EU Chief Negotiator for the Preparation and Conduct of the Negotiations, said that the EU wanted to succeed by reaching a deal with the British, not against them.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-723_en.htm |title=Speech by Michel Barnier, Chief Negotiator for the Preparation and Conduct of the Negotiations with the United Kingdom, at the plenary session of the European Committee of the Regions |date=22 March 2017 |website=[[European Commission]] |access-date=30 August 2018}} On 22 May the European Commission Council, following the approval of [[European Union negotiating directives for Brexit|negotiating directives]] which had been adopted by strong qualified majority (72% of the 27 Member States, i.e. 20 Member States representing 65% of the population of the EU27), authorised the opening of Article 50 discussions with the Commission appointed as the negotiator. It further confirmed that all agendas, EU position papers, Non-papers and EU text proposals will be released to the public and published on line.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-1405_en.htm |title=European Commission receives mandate to begin negotiations with the UK |website=European Commission |date=22 May 2017}} ===Intergovernmental organization=== [[Intergovernmental organization]]s also involved in Brexit uncertainty considerations include the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) and the [[International Air Transport Association]] (IATA). IATA expects an agreement to avoid disruption.{{cite magazine |url=http://www.air-cosmos.com/brexit-iata-veut-une-solution-rapide-104095 |title=Brexit : IATA veut une solution rapide |first=Jean-Baptiste |last=Heguy |date=5 December 2017 |magazine=[[Air & Cosmos]] |language=fr |accessdate=9 December 2017}} === Phases === EU27 guidelines include: * Agreement on the so-called "[[EU divorce bill|divorce bill]]"; * Agreement on rights of EU citizens living in the UK; * Agreement on the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic within the withdrawal phase. The second phase, covering the post-Brexit relationship between the EU27 and the UK, will begin "as soon as the European Council decides that sufficient progress has been made in the first phase towards reaching a satisfactory agreement on the arrangements for an orderly withdrawal".{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2017/04/29-euco-brexit-guidelines/ |title=European Council (Art. 50) guidelines for Brexit negotiations |date=29 April 2017 |website=European Council |access-date=9 September 2017}} The earliest opportunity for this decision was 19 October 2017, at a summit of EU leaders.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-30/brexit-watchers-your-guide-to-key-dates-in-coming-negotiations |title=Your Guide to Key Dates in the Brexit Negotiations |last=Chrysoloras |first=Nikos |date=30 March 2017 |website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=9 September 2017}} although at that meeting it was agreed to start negotiations during the December meeting.{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/23512/20-euco-conclusions-art50.pdf |title=Council Conclusions |date=20 October 2017 |website=European Council |access-date=8 December 2017}} ==Negotiation policy== {{Quote box |quote ="We recognise how important it is to provide business, the public sector and the public with as much certainty as possible. So ahead of, and throughout the negotiations, we will provide certainty wherever we can. We will provide as much information as we can without undermining the national interest." |source = {{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/589191/The_United_Kingdoms_exit_from_and_partnership_with_the_EU_Web.pdf |title=The United Kingdom's exit from and new partnership with the European Union |date=February 2017 |website=UK Government |page=9}} |align = left |width = 20% }} Some effects of the UK withdrawal could emerge before the UK and the EU27 conclude the Article 50 negotiation, as a result of policies existing when the negotiation begins, or some change of policy later. At the outset policy provisions binding on the EU include principles, aspirations and objectives set out in the TEU ([[Treaty on European Union]]) Preamble{{cite web |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Consolidated_version_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union/Preamble |title=Consolidated version of the Treaty on European Union|at=Peramble|via=Wikisource}} and Articles,{{cite web |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Consolidated_version_of_the_Treaty_on_European_Union/Title_I:_Common_Provisions |title=Consolidated version of the Treaty on European Union|at=Title I: Common Provisions|via=Wikisource}} of which :''Article 3'' mentions the promotion of "scientific and technological advance" in a context governed by "The Union's aim is to promote peace, its values and the well-being of its peoples", the Union's [[European Single Market|internal market]], "work for the [[sustainable development]] of Europe based on balanced economic growth and price stability, a highly competitive [[social market economy]], aiming at full employment and social progress", and the requirement that "The Union shall pursue its objectives by appropriate means commensurate with the competences which are conferred upon it in the Treaties", and :''Article 4'' mentions "competences not conferred upon the Union in the Treaties remain with the Member States". Policies mentioned in the Preamble include: – Achieve the strengthening and convergence of Member States' economies and establish an economic and monetary union including a single and stable currency, – Promote economic and social progress for their peoples, taking into account the principle of sustainable development and within the context of the accomplishment of the internal market and of reinforced cohesion and environmental protection, and implement policies ensuring that advances in economic integration are accompanied by parallel progress in other fields, – Establish a citizenship common to nationals of their countries, – Implement a common foreign and security policy including the progressive framing of a common defence policy, thereby reinforcing the European identity and its independence in order to promote peace, security and progress in Europe and in the world, – Facilitate the [[Freedom of movement for workers in the European Union|free movement of persons]], while ensuring the safety and security of their peoples, by establishing an area of freedom, security and justice. – Continue the process of creating an ever-closer union among the peoples of Europe, in which decisions are taken as closely as possible to the citizen in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. UK policy was stated in a [[white paper]] published in February 2017: ''The United Kingdom's exit from and new partnership with the European Union''.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/589191/The_United_Kingdoms_exit_from_and_partnership_with_the_EU_Web.pdf |title=The United Kingdom's exit from and new partnership with the European Union |date=February 2017 |website=UK Government}} In the white paper, UK negotiating policy was set out as twelve guiding principles: :''1.'' Providing certainty and clarity, including a "Great Repeal Bill" to remove the European Communities Act 1972 from the [[statute book]] and convert existing EU law into domestic law. :''2.'' Taking control of the UK statute book and ending the jurisdiction of the [[Court of Justice of the European Union]] in the UK. :''3.'' Strengthening the Union of all parts of the Kingdom, and remaining fully committed to the [[Good Friday Agreement|Belfast Agreement]] and its successors. :''4.'' Working to deliver a practical solution that allows for the maintenance of the [[Common Travel Area]] whilst protecting the integrity of the UK immigration system, and which protects the strong ties with Ireland. :''5.'' Controlling the number of EU nationals coming to the UK. :''6.'' Securing the status of EU citizens who are already living in the UK, and that of UK nationals in other Member States. :''7.'' Protecting and enhancing existing workers' rights. :''8.'' Forging a new partnership with the EU, including a wide reaching free trade agreement, and seeking a mutually beneficial new customs agreement with the EU. :''9.'' Forging free trade relationships across the world. :''10.'' Remaining at the vanguard of science and innovation and seeking continued close collaboration with the UK's European partners. :''11.'' Continuing to work with the EU to preserve European security, to fight terrorism, and to uphold justice across Europe. :''12.'' Seeking a phased process of implementation, in which both the UK and the EU institutions and the remaining EU Member States prepare for the new arrangements. === Pre–negotiation meetings === A meeting at [[10 Downing Street]] took place on 6 April 2017 between [[Theresa May]] and [[Donald Tusk]] to discuss "the way ahead on Brexit".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/pm-to-meet-donald-tusk-to-for-brexit-discussions-at-number-10-10827086 |title=PM to meet Donald Tusk for Brexit discussions at Number 10 |website=Sky News |date=6 April 2017}} Another meeting took place in London on 20 April 2017, this time between Theresa May and [[Antonio Tajani]] to discuss the rights of EU citizens.{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/antonio-tajani-meet-theresa-may-in-london-parliament-president/ |title=Antonio Tajani to meet Theresa May in London |website=Politico.eu |date=13 April 2017}} After 20 April meeting, Antonio Tajani said that the UK and EU27 timetables fitted well together, with a two-year exit deal negotiation followed by a three-year transition phase. A 10 Downing Street meeting between Theresa May, [[Michel Barnier]] and [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] took place on 26 April to discuss the withdrawal process. May reiterated the UK's aim for a "deep and special partnership" after Brexit.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-39722903 |title=Brexit: Theresa May meets EU's chief negotiator for talks |website=BBC News |date=27 April 2017}} At a meeting on 29 April 2017 the EU27 unanimously endorsed the draft guidelines with no debate. A meeting took place between Michel Barnier and both houses of the Irish parliament on 11 May, where Barnier assured members of [[Dáil Éireann]] and [[Seanad Éireann]] that Europe would "work with you to avoid a hard border".{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/eu-chief-tells-ireland-he-will-work-to-avoid-hard-border-post-brexit-10872491 |title=Barnier tells Ireland he'll work to avoid hard border post-Brexit |website=Sky News |date=11 May 2017}} Barnier went on to say that "the Irish border issue would be one of his three priorities in the negotiations," and that "there is always an answer".{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-39889292 |title=Brexit Irish border answer can be found – EU's Barnier |date=12 May 2017 |website=BBC News |access-date=13 May 2017}} The UK retains its full EU rights until Brexit, and the EU is seeking to increase their budget, leading to the possibility that Britain may veto EU budget increases, which in the immediate term amount to 4 billion euros. A continued British veto would have far-reaching consequences and "will hurt us" according to German MEP Jens Geier.{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/angela-merkel-veraergert-ueber-jean-claude-juncker-nach-brexit-dinner-a-1146299.html |title= Treffen mit May: Merkel verärgert über Juncker nach Brexit-Dinner |trans-title=Meeting with May: Merkel annoyed with Juncker after Brexit dinner |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |language=de |date=6 May 2017 |accessdate=15 May 2017}} == Negotiation phase 1: withdrawal arrangements == === June 2017 === On 19 June 2017, David Davis arrived in Brussels to start negotiations with Michel Barnier.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40321271 |title=Brexit negotiations: Barnier rules out 'concessions' |date=19 June 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=23 June 2017}} Terms of reference were agreed, and dates were set for four-week cycles, to culminate in a fifth round of negotiations in the week commencing 9 October. Negotiating groups were established for three topics: the rights of EU citizens living in Britain and vice versa; Britain's outstanding financial obligations to the EU; and the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/eu-uk-art-50-terms-reference_agreed_amends_en.pdf |title=Terms of Reference for the Article 50 TEU negotiations |last= |first= |date=19 June 2017 |website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=29 August 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8017 |title=Brexit: the talks begin |date=12 July 2017 |website=House of Commons Library |accessdate=20 August 2017}}{{cite news |title=Let the Brussels games begin |url=https://www.economist.com/britain/2017/06/22/let-the-brussels-games-begin |accessdate=22 September 2018 |publisher=Economist.com}} === July === Four days of talks, largely between officials, were held in Brussels on 17–20 July. Progress was made in understanding each other's positions.{{cite web |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8068 |title=Brexit: the July negotiations |date=2 August 2017 |website=House of Commons Library |accessdate=20 August 2017}} On citizens' rights, a joint paper compared the positions of the two parties in tabular form.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/joint-technical-note-on-the-comparison-of-eu-uk-positions-on-citizens-rights |title=Joint technical note on the comparison of EU-UK positions on citizens' rights |last= |first= |date=20 July 2017 |website=Department for Exiting the European Union|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |accessdate=30 September 2017}} On Irish border issues, both parties stated that they remained committed to the [[Good Friday Agreement]]. Michel Barnier called for clarification from the UK in the August round on the financial settlement, citizens' rights and Ireland, including on how the UK intends to maintain the [[Common Travel Area]].{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-2108_en.htm |title=Speaking points by Michel Barnier at the press conference following the second round of Article 50 negotiations with the United Kingdom |date=20 July 2017 |website=European Commission |accessdate=20 August 2017}} === August === Talks were held in Brussels on 28–31 August. Agreement was reached on points including protecting the rights of frontier workers (those living in one country and working in another); recognition by the UK of social security contributions made both before and after exit; and continuation of healthcare reimbursement for UK citizens who are in the EU27 on exit day and vice versa.{{cite web |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8082 |title=Brexit: the August negotiations |date=6 September 2017 |website=House of Commons Library |accessdate=9 September 2017}} The joint paper comparing the two parties' positions was updated. Speaking at the conclusion of the talks, Michel Barnier highlighted two areas of disagreement: the role of the European Court of Justice in enforcing citizens' rights, and the extent of the UK's financial obligations. He stated "Time is passing quickly" and added that "at the current speed, we are far from being able to recommend to the European Council that there has been sufficient progress in order to start discussions on the future relationship".{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-3043_en.htm |title=Speech by Michel Barnier at the press conference following the third round of Article 50 negotiations with the United Kingdom |last= |first= |date=31 August 2017 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 September 2017}} ===September=== On 7 September the EU Task Force published guiding principles for the dialogue on Ireland / Northern Ireland which reiterated and expanded the principles given in 29 April guidelines, in particular the protection of the Good Friday Agreement and the continuation of the Common Travel Area.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-17-3105_en.htm |title=Brexit: European Commission publishes guiding principles on Ireland and Northern Ireland |last= |first= |date=7 September 2017 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 December 2017}} The fourth round of talks began on 25 September, having been delayed by one week as Theresa May was due to deliver a speech in Florence on the 22nd.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-12/u-k-eu-are-said-to-delay-next-round-of-brexit-negotiations |title=U.K. and EU Delay Next Round of Brexit Negotiations |last= |first= |date=12 September 2017 |website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=26 September 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} She proposed a transitional "implementation period" of "around two years" and said that the UK "will honour commitments" so as to not make other EU countries pay more or receive less during the current EU budget period.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/9b183886-9faf-11e7-8cd4-932067fbf946 |title=Five key points from Theresa May's speech |last1=Wright |first1=Robert |date=22 September 2017|newspaper=Financial Times |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |accessdate=26 September 2017|url-access=subscription}} The programme for the round of talks arranged for meetings between the "Principals" and for three negotiating groups covering citizens' rights, financial settlement and other separation issues, while Northern Ireland issues would be addressed by the "Coordinators", and governance of the withdrawal agreement was also for discussion at technical level.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/programme-for-fourth-round-of-uk-eu-article-50-negotiations |title=Programme for fourth round of UK-EU Article 50 negotiations |date=25 September 2017 |website=Department for Exiting the European Union |access-date=30 August 2018}} David Davis repeated Theresa May's request for a time-limited implementation period. The UK offered to incorporate the Withdrawal Agreement into UK law and ensure the UK courts can refer directly to it, but there was no agreement on the role of the European Court of Justice and the standing of future ECJ case law.{{Cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/859890/Brexit-news-EU-David-Davis-Michel-Barnier-progress-talks |title=Brexit breakthrough? How FOUR key battlegrounds from the fourth round of talks unfolded |last=Gutteridge |first=Nick |date=28 September 2017|newspaper=Daily Express |access-date=1 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} Mr Barnier welcomed the UK's commitment regarding payments into the current EU budget plan, but expressed reservations about obligations beyond 2020. Mr Davis said the UK was not yet in a position to quantify its commitments. There were constructive discussions on the Irish border, but no substantive progress.{{cite web |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8104 |title=Brexit: the September negotiations |date=6 October 2017 |website=House of Commons Library |accessdate=14 October 2017}} The UK accepted the EU's definition of 'citizens lawfully resident before the cut off date', although that date was not agreed. There was agreement on the definitions of permanent and temporary residence. The UK offered a more generous "right of return" (after absence for longer than two consecutive years) than the minimum rights under current EU law. Rights of future family members remains a point of disagreement. The joint paper comparing the two parties' positions was again updated. === October === The fifth round of negotiations was held on 9, 10 and 12 October. There was technical progress on citizens' rights, although divergences remained on aspects of family reunion and the export from the UK of social security benefits.{{cite web |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8125 |title=Brexit: the October negotiations |last= |first= |date=27 October 2017 |website=House of Commons Library|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 October 2017}} The UK stated an intention to offer a simple process for registration of EU citizens. On the Irish border, work continued to map out current areas of cooperation and build a picture of the future challenges.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41585430 |title=Deadlock over UK's Brexit bill - Barnier |last= |first= |date=12 October 2017 |website=BBC News|access-date=14 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}} On the financial settlement, Michel Barnier welcomed the commitment made by Theresa May in her Florence speech, but no negotiations took place because the UK was not ready to give details of what it would pay. Barnier said this issue had reached an impasse.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_STATEMENT-17-3921_en.htm |title=Press statement by Michel Barnier following the fifth round of Article 50 negotiations with the United Kingdom |last= |first= |date=12 October 2017 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=14 October 2017}} This round of talks completed the timetable agreed in June, with no further rounds scheduled.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-talks-negotiations-deadlock-article-50-theresa-may-eu-david-davis-a7999156.html |title=No further Brexit talks yet scheduled as negotiations hit deadlock |last=Stone |first=Jon |date=14 October 2017|newspaper=The Independent|access-date=15 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-27/u-k-stalling-on-new-brexit-talks-as-clock-ticks-down-to-summit |title=The U.K. Is Stalling on New Brexit Talks |last1=Ross |first1=Tim |last2=Wishart |first2=Ian |date=27 October 2017 |website=Bloomberg |access-date=30 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} === November === Further talks were held in Brussels on 9 and 10 November.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/programme-for-uk-eu-article-50-negotiations-9-10-november |title=Programme for UK-EU Article 50 negotiations, 9–10 November |last= |first= |date=9 November 2017 |website=UK Government |language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 November 2017}} Speaking at the closing press conference, Michel Barnier confirmed that clarification on financial commitments by the UK was required within the next two weeks.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/nov/10/uk-given-two-week-deadline-to-make-concessions-on-brexit-divorce-bill |title=EU gives UK two-week deadline on Brexit divorce bill |last1=Boffey |first1=Daniel |date=10 November 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=10 November 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |last2=Rankin |first2=Jennifer|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} If the informal deadline is not met, the next phase of negotiations will not start in December, said Barnier.{{cite web |title=Speech by Michel Barnier following the sixth round of Article 50 negotiations with the United Kingdom |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-4545_en.htm |website=European Commission |accessdate=11 November 2017 |date=10 November 2017}} EU diplomats have described the situation as a "[[chicken and egg]] dilemma", as the EU will only start working on transition guidelines if Britain makes progress on financial issues by the end of November 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/51b59608-c4a2-11e7-b2bb-322b2cb39656|url-access=subscription |title=EU gives UK up to 3 weeks to make Brexit bill offer |last=Barker |first=Alex |last2=Parker |first2=George |date=9 November 2017|newspaper=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=10 November 2017}} By 17 November, however, Donald Tusk said there was no deadlock in talks between Britain and the EU following a meeting with Theresa May in Gothenburg, Sweden and that he was optimistic that negotiations could move on to the next phase in December.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-tusk-may/eus-tusk-no-deadlock-on-brexit-very-cautious-but-optimistic-idUSKBN1DH20I |title=EU's Tusk: no deadlock on Brexit, very cautious but optimistic |date=17 November 2017 |website=Reuters |accessdate=9 December 2017}} Discussions on the financial settlement took place later in the month, led by [[Oliver Robbins]] for the UK and [[Sabine Weyand]] for the EU.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/11/28/exclusive-britain-eu-agree-brexit-divorce-bill/ |title=Exclusive: Britain and the EU agree Brexit divorce bill |last=Foster |first=Peter |date=28 November 2017|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|access-date=2 December 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} === December 2017 === Negotiations between officials led to a draft agreement which was expected to be finalised at a meeting between Jean-Claude Juncker and Theresa May in Brussels on 4 December. There was progress on the financial settlement and citizens' rights, but the meeting was abandoned after Northern Ireland's [[Democratic Unionist Party]] objected to arrangements for the Irish border; the agreement had earlier received the support of [[Leo Varadkar]], Ireland's [[Taoiseach]] (prime minister).{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/983b64e8-d8e0-11e7-a039-c64b1c09b482 |title=Brexit deal falls through over Irish border dispute |last1=Barker |first1=Alex |last2=Beesley |first2=Arthur |date=4 December 2017 |newspaper=Financial Times |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 December 2017 |last3=Parker |first3=George|url-access=subscription}} Talks continued on the following days, leading to publication on 8 December of a joint report setting out the commitments to be reflected in the Withdrawal Agreement. "Agreement in principle" was reached on the three areas: * protecting the rights of Union citizens in the UK and UK citizens in the Union * the framework for addressing the unique circumstances of Northern Ireland * the financial settlement.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/joint_report.pdf |title=Joint report from the negotiators of the European Union and the United Kingdom Government on progress during phase 1 of negotiations under Article 50 TEU on the United Kingdom's orderly withdrawal from the European Union |last= |first= |date=8 December 2017 |website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=8 December 2017}} A joint technical note gave details of the consensus on citizens' rights.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/publications/joint-technical-note-expressing-detailed-consensus-uk-and-eu-positions-respect-citizens-rights_en |title=Joint technical note expressing the detailed consensus of the UK and EU positions on Citizens' Rights |last= |first= |date=8 December 2017 |website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 December 2017}} Topics postponed to a later phase included: * rights of UK citizens resident in an EU27 country on the withdrawal date to move to another EU27 country, and their right to return to the UK * recognition of professional qualifications, beyond those already mutually recognised at the withdrawal date. Juncker described the agreement as a "breakthrough" Brexit deal.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-42277040 |title='Breakthrough' deal in Brexit talks |date=8 December 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} The second phase of negotiations – concerning Britain's post-Brexit trade with the EU – will now be able to take place as a result of the agreement.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/britain-and-eu-reach-divorce-deal-to-move-on-to-new-phase-in-brexit-talks/2017/12/08/4525b332-dba4-11e7-a241-0848315642d0_story.html |title=Britain and E.U. reach divorce deal to move on to new phase in Brexit talks |first=Michael |last=Birnbaum |date=8 December 2017 |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu/may-travels-to-brussels-in-hope-of-clinching-brexit-deal-idUSKBN1E20G6 |title=Britain, EU clinch Brexit 'breakthrough' with move to trade talks |date=9 December 2017 |website=Reuters |accessdate=9 December 2017}} === January 2018 === Discussions on the outstanding issues continued and were described as "low-key".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jan/29/brexit-uk-given-warning-over-outstanding-divorce-issues-eu |title=Brexit: UK given warning over outstanding divorce issues |last=Rankin |first=Jennifer |date=29 January 2018|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 January 2018}} === February 2018 === Several meetings took place between the negotiators.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/publications/programme-eu-uk-article-50-negotiations_en |title=Programme of EU-UK Article 50 negotiations |last= |first= |date=2 February 2018 |website=European Commission |language=en|access-date=25 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/publications/programme-eu-uk-article-50-negotiations-0_en |title=Programme of EU-UK Article 50 negotiations |last= |first= |date=16 February 2018 |website=European Commission |language=en|access-date=25 February 2018}} ===March 2018=== Due to the ambivalence of UK on the [[Irish border question]], Tusk declared in March 2018 "We know today that the UK Government rejects a customs and regulatory border down the Irish Sea, the EU single market, and the customs union."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-eu-talks-irish-border-tusk-varadkar-northern-ireland-uk-solution-dup-a8246216.html |title=EU freezes Brexit talks until Britain produces Irish border solution |date=8 March 2018 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=3 April 2018}} Tusk's has said that talks cannot proceed around this issue, that it must be resolved first.{{cite web |url=https://news.sky.com/story/amp/may-warned-there-must-be-an-ireland-first-approach-to-brexit-talks-11281755 |title=May warned there must be an 'Ireland first' approach to Brexit talks |last=McGuinness |first=Alan |date=8 March 2018 |website=Sky News |access-date=30 August 2018}} == Negotiation phase 2: transitional arrangements == The second phase of the negotiation covers the arrangements for transition towards the UK's withdrawal, together with the framework for the future relationship. On 15 December 2017, the European Council adopted guidelines for this phase. The document confirmed that progress in the first phase was "sufficient", while stating that commitments made in that phase must be "translated faithfully into legal terms as quickly as possible"; and notes the UK's proposal for a transition period of "around two years".{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2017/12/15/european-council-art-50-guidelines-for-brexit-negotiations/ |title=European Council (Art. 50) guidelines for Brexit negotiations |last= |first= |date=15 December 2017 |website=European Council|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 December 2017}} On 20 December, the European Commission published a draft of the negotiating directives stating a transition period should not last beyond 31 December 2020. During the transition the United Kingdom would not be part of agreements the EU made on behalf of its members with third countries, such as [[CETA]].{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/annex_commissions_recommendation_20-12-2017.pdf |title=Commission's recommendation including supplementary negotiating directives |last= |first= |date=20 December 2017 |website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=21 December 2017}} The European Council adopted and published negotiating directives on 29 January 2018. These state that the whole of the [[EU acquis]] (the rights and obligations binding on all member states) will continue to apply to the UK during the transition period. The UK will continue to be within the customs union and the single market, while no longer participating in EU decision-making.{{cite web |url=https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2018/01/29/brexit-council-article-50-adopts-negotiating-directives-on-the-transition-period/ |title=Brexit: Council (Article 50) adopts negotiating directives on the transition period |last= |first= |date=29 January 2018 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=31 January 2018}} The UK's position was outlined in speeches and interviews.{{cite web |title=Brexit: who has said what about transition? |url=https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-8238 |website=House of Commons Library |accessdate=28 February 2018 |date=23 February 2018}} In March 2018 resolution, the MEPs expect an EU-UK agreement which safeguard the framework of existing commercial relationships between the EU and third countries with consistency for keeping a tuned tariff and quota system and rules of origin for products vis-à-vis third and a countries,{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//NONSGML+TA+P8-TA-2018-0069+0+DOC+PDF+V0//EN |title=Guidelines on the framework of future EU-UK relations |date=14 March 2018 |website=European Parliament |access-date=30 August 2018}} and also a transitional arrangements fully compatible with WTO obligations to not disrupt trade relations with third countries. On 19 March 2018, the transition period has been agreed while it can not be considered legally binding until after ratification of a wider agreement on withdrawal: "Nothing is agreed until everything is agreed,".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/19/world/europe/uk-brexit-eu.html |title=U.K. Reaches Brexit Transition Deal With E.U. |last=Castle |first=Stephen |date=19 March 2018 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=30 August 2018}} On 19 March 2018, the document was published; text in green has been agreed.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/draft_agreement_coloured.pdf |title=Draft Agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community |date=19 March 2018 |website=European Commission |access-date=30 August 2018}} (75% agreed).{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/mar/19/uk-and-eu-agree-terms-for-brexit-transition-deal |title=Theresa May under fire over Brexit transition deal |first1=Daniel |last1=Boffey |first2=Lisa |last2=O'Carroll |first3=Anushka |last3=Asthana |date=19 March 2018|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=3 April 2018}} *green areas include citizens rights and the financial settlement. *white areas concern police and judicial cooperation. *in yellow: The Northern Ireland border representing the agreement struck in December but the lack of clarity on what that could mean in practice.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-transition-period-deal-agreement-eu-uk-david-davis-barnier-latest-updates-a8263211.html |title=EU and UK have agreed a deal on the Brexit transition period |date=19 March 2018 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=3 April 2018}} A curious development with this release was the avoidance of mentioning what will happen with the free movement rights of UK citizens living abroad on the basis of those rights. The section which previously stated that those rights would be removed, article 32, was removed from the agreement, although references to it remain in other parts of the document. ==Negotiation phase 3: trade relations with EU after Brexit== === July 2018 === The [[European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018]] that became law in the United Kingdom on 26 June 2018, and [[European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018#Connected legislation: world and cross-border trade|two bills]] that were then progressing through Parliament relating to world and cross-border trade after the withdrawal, allow for various outcomes including no negotiated settlement. The two bills passed from the House of Commons to the House of Lords in July 2018. On 6 July 2018, the UK Government announced that the May Cabinet had agreed that it should propose a "UK-EU free trade area which establishes a common rule book for industrial goods and agricultural products" [but not services] after Brexit.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/06/theresa-may-secures-approval-from-cabinet-to-negotiate-soft-brexit |title=Theresa May faces Tory anger over soft Brexit proposal |date=2 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} A few days earlier, senior EU officials had intimated that a proposal for "partial" membership of the [[European Single Market]] would not be welcomed.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/02/uk-latest-brexit-proposal-is-unrealistic-say-eu-officials |title=UK's latest Brexit proposal is unrealistic, say EU officials |last=Rankin |first=Jennifer |date=2 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} Before the Cabinet meeting at [[Chequers]] on 6 July, Barnier stated that the EU would accept a trade agreement with the UK if it does not damage the European Single Market. However, he said the EU would not shift its own red line on the single market, which he said was "not and never should be seen as a big supermarket; it is economic, cultural and social life, it should be developed in all its dimensions".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/06/michel-barnier-eu-willing-to-compromise-if-uk-softens-brexit-red-lines |title=Michel Barnier: EU willing to compromise if UK softens red lines |last=O'Carroll |first=Lisa |date=6 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} On 10 July 2018, Barnier announced that 80% of the Brexit deal was now complete.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2018/jul/10/theresa-may-new-cabinet-boris-johnson-resignation-brexit-live |title=Two Tory party vice-chairs quit over Chequers Brexit plan – as it happened |first1=Peter |last1=Walker |first2=Jessica |last2=Elgot |first3=Graham |last3=Russell |first4=Kevin |last4=Rawlinson |date=10 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} The government published the "[[Chequers plan]]" on 12 July 2018. In response to a statement about it by the Secretary of State, the opposition spokesman said that it was a disgrace that it had been shown to the media from 9 a.m. that morning but it had not been shown to MPs until hours later.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/12/brexit-white-paper-seeks-free-movement-for-skilled-workers-and-students |title=Brexit white paper seeks free movement for skilled workers and students |last1=Sabbagh |first1=Dan |last2=Walker |first2=Peter |date=12 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} While the President of the United States [[Donald Trump]] was on a visit to the United Kingdom on 13 July 2018, his comment – made in an exclusive interview with ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' – that the UK would probably not get a trade deal with the US if the prime minister's plan went ahead, was widely published in the media.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44815558 |title=Donald Trump and Theresa May meet amid Brexit storm |date=13 July 2018 |website=BBC News |access-date=30 August 2018}} Later the same day he stated, in a joint press conference with May at Chequers, that the Prime Minister was "doing a fantastic job" as prime minister, and contrary reports were "fake news", but he only asked for an "even" deal with the UK, and, complaining about EU trade barriers and tariffs on cars, he said that the US lost $151 billion to the EU.{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-news/donald-trump-teresa-may-joint-press-conference-british-pm-uk-visit-today-2018-07-13-live-updates/ |title=Trump praises Theresa May after he questioned her Brexit plan in British tabloid interview |date=13 July 2018 |website=CBS News}}{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/07/13/trump-theresa-may-brexit-718462 |title=Trump eases up on May and Brexit: 'Whatever you do is OK with me' |website=Politico.com |date=13 July 2018}} ''The Sun'', which had conducted the interview with Trump that was the original source of the comment,{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/6766531/trump-may-brexit-us-deal-off/ |title=I told May how to do Brexit but she wrecked it — US trade deal is off! |date=13 July 2018 |newspaper=The Sun}} afterwards denied that it produced fake news and published the interview verbatim.{{cite news |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/6775873/the-suns-astonishing-interview-with-donald-trump-reverberated-around-the-world-yesterday/ |title=The Sun's explosive interview with Donald Trump stuns the world |date=13 July 2018|newspaper=The Sun}} While the negotiations continued, the UK government confirmed in the House of Commons on 19 July 2018 that the UK would be leaving the EU on 29 March 2019, as stated in the withdrawal act and the white paper.{{cite news |url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/991165/Brexit-news-update-Article-50-extension-Peter-Bone-UK-Parliament-latest |title=EU plot will fail: Bone forces Brexit minister to promise Article 50 won't be extended |date=19 July 2018 |newspaper=Daily Express |access-date=30 August 2018}} The first meeting of Dominic Raab, the newly appointed UK Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, with the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, was later on the same day (19 July 2018) in Brussels. Raab offered to meet Barnier throughout August to "intensify" talks, while both the UK and EU were insisting that reaching agreement by the autumn on the UK withdrawal in March 2019 was still very much on the cards.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44880968 |title=New Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab vows to 'intensify' talks |date=19 July 2018 |website=BBC News |access-date=30 August 2018}} On 20 July 2018, May repeated her opposition to the EU's proposals for the [[Irish border question]] during a speech in Belfast, stating that the EU must "evolve" and that there would be no further compromises over the issue.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-44892385 |title=EU must 'evolve' Brexit position - PM |date=20 July 2018 |website=BBC News}} Just hours after the Prime Minister's remarks, Barnier expressed skepticism towards the Chequers plan.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-eu-uk-chequers-white-paper-michel-barnier-theresa-may-a8456416.html |title=EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier takes apart Theresa May's Chequers white paper plan |newspaper=The Independent |date=20 July 2018}} On 24 July 2018, May announced that she would now lead the Brexit negotiations with the EU and that Raab was now only "deputizing" on her behalf.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-44941792 |title=May takes control of Brexit negotiations |date=24 July 2018 |website=BBC News}}{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/24/brexit-raab-sidelined-as-may-takes-control-of-eu-negotiations |title=Brexit: Raab 'sidelined' as May takes control of EU negotiations |first=Pippa |last=Crerar |date=24 July 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}} On 26 July, Barnier held another meeting with Raab and both stated afterwards stated in a joint press conference that "sufficient progress" had been made in the trade negotiations. Raab also stated during the joint press conference that "a lot has been achieved."{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/07/26/eus-chief-negotiator-major-issues-deal-brexit-negotiations/ |title=EU's chief negotiator: there are 'major issues' to deal with in Brexit negotiations |first=Mickey |last=Carroll |date=26 July 2018|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}} Barnier also stated that both sides wanted a wide-ranging free trade deal and that he would meet again with Raab in mid-August.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/44964521 |title=Barnier rules out UK's customs proposal |date=26 July 2018 |website=BBC News}} However, he also acknowledged that obstacles remained due to the White Paper's proposal to allow Britain to collect custom duties on behalf of the EU and that the proposal would never be accepted for any non-member. Barnier also stated that the only other challenge in the trade negotiations was finalizing an agreement between both sides concerning a [[Irish border question#Backstop agreement|backstop that guarantees a frictionless border]] between Ireland and Northern Ireland. Barnier stated that the EU holds "no objections in principle" to the backstop, but has "doubts that it can be done without putting at risk the integrity of [[European Union Customs Union|our customs union]], [[European Single Market|our common commercial policy]], our regulatory policy and our fiscal revenue."{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-barnier/eu-rejects-britains-key-elements-of-special-customs-plan-after-brexit-idUSKBN1KG2K0 |title=EU rejects Britain's key elements of special customs plan after Brexit |first=Jan |last=Strupczewski |website=Reuters |date=26 July 2018}} === August === On 2 August 2018, Barnier announced the EU was "ready to improve the EU proposal" on the |first=Asa |last=Bennett |date=9 August 2018|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}} Agreeing to the single market proposal could potentially mean that Britain will be unable to change laws in order to give it a competitive edge against the EU and could hinder any chance of signing additional trade deals. On 16 August 2018, EU and British officials began two days of talks to resolve the issue concerning the Irish border.{{cite web |url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/uk-europe/news/ministers-stay-away-as-brexit-officials-resume-talks-on-irish-border/ |title=Ministers stay away as Brexit officials resume talks on Irish border |website=Euractiv.com |date=16 August 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.newstalk.com/Irish-border-tops-agenda-as-Brexit-talks-set-to-resume- |title=Irish border tops agenda as Brexit talks set to resume |website=Newstalk.com}} However, Barnier and Raab did not attend the talks and both sides indicated there would be little chance of a breakthrough. On 16 August, leaked documents obtained by ''[[Buzzfeed News]]'' showed that May had now set plans for a "no-deal" Brexit for "84 areas of life."{{cite web |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alexspence/a-new-leak-reveals-84-areas-of-british-life-the-uk?utm_term=.pfvqmPjpn#.txq9Ye1dw |title=A New Leak Reveals The Government's "No Deal" Brexit Papers Will Cover 84 Areas Of British Life |website=Buzzfeed |date=16 August 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/theresa-may-government-has-no-deal-brexit-plans-for-84-areas-of-british-life-full-list-2018-8?r=UK&IR=T |title=Theresa May's government has 'no deal' Brexit plans for 84 areas of British life — here's the full list |website=Business Insider}} The May government intends to start publicly disclosing the plans in the following week as a warning to the EU. On 18 August, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported that the first batch of the papers detailing a no-deal Brexit are due to be published on 23 August.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/08/18/tories-launch-project-no-fear-ensure-eu-medicine-car-parts-will/ |title=Tories launch project 'no fear' as 'no-deal' scenario is set out |first1=Peter |last1=Foster |first2=Christopher |last2=Hope |date=18 August 2018|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph}} On 21 August 2018, Barnier said that the EU and Britain would not reach a trade deal by the October EU summit and that an emergency summit would have to be held in either November or December.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu/eu-diplomats-expect-delay-in-brexit-deal-beyond-october-target-idUSKCN1L611G |title=EU expects delay in Brexit deal beyond October target |last=Baczynska |first=Gabriela |date=21 August 2018 |website=Reuters |access-date=22 August 2018|language=en-US}} Both sides still disagree over a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/08/21/dominic-raab-michel-barnier-give-update-brexit-talks/ |title=EU should not be blamed if there is no Brexit deal, Michel Barnier says |first1=James |last1=Crisp |first2=James |last2=Rothwell |date=21 August 2018 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=30 August 2018}} While there is a possibly that there could be a summit in December, this is highly unlikely to occur and November would be the most likely month to hold an emergency summit. Gabriele Zimmer, a leftist German member of the European Parliament who deals with Brexit, told Reuters "we didn't see any concrete proposal that would work on the Irish border issue. November is the last moment. December is already too late for us." Despite the setback, however, Raab and Barnier both agreed to hold "continuous talks" in an effort to resolve the deadlock.{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/aug/21/uk-and-eu-to-enter-continuous-talks-to-resolve-brexit-deadlock |title=UK and EU to enter 'continuous' talks to resolve Brexit deadlock |website=Sky News |accessdate=30 August 2018}} Barnier stated that talks had previously been held in "rounds" every few weeks.{{cite news |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/21/uk-to-hold-continuous-brexit-negotiations-as-fears-grow-britain-could-leave-eu-without-deal-7868117/ |title=UK to hold continuous Brexit talks as fears grow Britain web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/1032868/Brexit-news-Theresa-May-Brussels-European-Council-Ireland-UK-EU-deal-latest|title='NOW IS THE TIME!' May issues Brexit rallying cry ahead of crunch EU talks|first=Joe Barnes, Brussels |last=Correspondent |date=17 October 2018 |website=Express.co.uk}}{{cite web |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/10/17/brexit-live-michel-barnier-offers-extend-transition-period-ahead |title=Brexiteers express fury at plan to delay UK's final departure from EU |first1=James |last1= Rothwell |first2=Rob |last2=Crilly|date=17 October 2018 |website=Telegraph.co.uk}} The same day, Varadkar announced a major concession over the backstop, agreeing to make it only temporary.{{cite web |url= https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/1032882/Brexit-news-Theresa-May-Ireland-border-UK-EU-deal-latest |title=Brexit BREAKTHROUGH: Ireland CONCEDES on backstop as May seals another victory |first1=Joe|last1=Barnes |date=17 October 2018 |access-date=18 October 2018 |website= express.co.uk}} Varadkar also stated that he wished to preserve current trade relations with Britain and hinted that another summit would be held in November. The Polish government, which has broken ranks with several other EU governments to support Britain's Brexit stance,{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/poland-breaks-ranks-from-eu-brexit-unity/|title=Poland breaks ranks from EU Brexit unity|date=20 September 2018|website=Politico.eu}} also warned other EU leaders not to "play with fire." During the summit, May rejected another drafted trade deal offered by the EU which would've extended the transition period, due to the fact that it would've resulted in adding around £5bn to the £39bn "divorce bill."{{cite web|url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/brexit-theresa-may-rejected-eu-175924850.html|title=Brexit: Theresa May rejected EU offer to break deadlock because it would add billions to divorce bill|website=Uk.news.yahoo.com}} On the first day, October 17, May met with Macron, Varadkar, Tusk and Juncker and also delivered a 30-minute speech to all 27 EU leaders.{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/7513925/brexit-deal-latest-theresa-may-confronts-eu-leaders/|title=EU WHAT? Brexit deal latest – Theresa May says Britain could stay tied to EU for another year in last-ditch bid to cut deal at Brussels summit|date=17 October 2018|access-date=18 October 2018|first1=Tom|last1=Newton Dunn|first2=Nick|last2=Gutteridge|first3=Hugo|last3=Gye|first4=Natasha|last4=Clark|website=thesun.co.uk}} Following her speech, European Parliament chief [[Antonio Tajani]] stated "the tone was more relaxed than in Salzburg, undoubtedly. There was a message of goodwill and readiness to reach an agreement, but I didn't perceive anything substantially new in terms of content as I listened to Mrs May." EU leaders also cancelled their plans to hold an extraordinary summit in November due to lack of progress.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-summit-latest-eu-leaders-november-deal-vote-theresa-may-a8589326.html|title=EU leaders decide to shelve plans for Brexit summit in November until ‘decisive progress’ is made|website=Independent.co.uk}}[https://www.newstalk.com/consent.php?return=R27i4qM853pd5FTZrUpGy%2ByMcBr45iuk7oBb99SpipqXwgCcZV%2Bh8dBy90HVH9Nlv5K0FzYskhuNdrh4ScLFGZS3TgnXGiNRkica0OaoyB2VU%2B6ivLdKmHFrcS1Yfi9N] {{dead link|date=November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/live-eu-cautious-on-brexit-deal-prospects-at-brussels-summit-11527852|title=LIVE: EU leaders drop plan for 'extraordinary' Brexit summit in November|website=News.sky.com}} On 18 October, Spain reached an agreement with Britain and agreed to no longer hold any objection to the nearby British coastal peninsula of [[Gibraltar]] leaving the EU with Britain.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-gibraltar/spain-says-agreement-reached-on-gibraltar-status-in-brexit-negotiations-idUSKCN1MS2DH|title=Spain says agreement reached on Gibraltar status in Brexit...|website=Reuters.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/spain-says-agreement-reached-gibraltar-status-brexit-negotiations-150703800.html|title=Spain says agreement reached on Gibraltar status in Brexit negotiations|website=Yahoo.com}} Spanish Prime Minister [[Pedro Sánchez (politician)|Pedro Sánchez]] even stated “Gibraltar will no longer be a problem in arriving at a Brexit deal." Any dispute between Britain and Spain over the status of Gibraltar will also no longer affect a potential trade agreement between Britain and the EU.{{cite web|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2018/10/18/inenglish/1539873272_150898.html|title=At Brussels summit, Spain’s PM is hopeful of progress on Gibraltar|first=Susana|last=Urra|date=18 October 2018|website=Elpais.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/news/world/uk-spain-reach-brexit-deal-over-gibraltar-spanish-pm/article/534934|title=UK, Spain reach Brexit deal over Gibraltar: Spanish PM|date=18 October 2018|website=Digitaljournal.com}} On 21 October, it was reported that trade negotiations between Britain and the EU were now 95% complete and that May had managed to not only resolve the issue surrounding Gibraltar's EU departure, but had also managed to develop a protocol concerning the UK's military presence in Cyprus and agreed to a mechanism for resolving any future disputes with the EU.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/21/eu-withdrawal-deal-theresa-may-commons|title=EU withdrawal deal is 95% settled, Theresa May to tell Commons|first=Dan|last=Sabbagh|date=21 October 2018|website=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/brexit/eu-withdrawal-deal-is-95percent-settled-theresa-may-to-tell-commons/ar-BBOHuFY?li=AA59G2|title=EU withdrawal deal is 95% settled, Theresa May to tell Commons|website=Msn.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu/with-divorce-deal-almost-done-may-repeats-rejection-of-eu-proposal-on-northern-ireland-idUSKCN1MV0YE|title=UK's May tries to calm Brexit rebels, says deal almost done|first=Kylie|last=MacLellan|website=Reuters.com}}{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/theresa-may-to-set-out-brexit-progress-in-crunch-speech-to-mps-11532071|title='Brexit deal is 95% complete' - May will tell MPs in crunch speech|website=News.sky.com}} On October 22, May confirmed this during a speech in the House of Commons.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-45938444|title=May says 95% of Brexit deal now agreed|date=22 October 2018|website=Bbc.com}} The British Prime Minister also laid the four elements related to the remaining 5% which remained unresolved, all of which are related to the Irish border.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/22/theresa-may-brexit-eu-final-deal-backstop|title=May says MPs must 'hold their nerve' to approve final Brexit deal|first1=Dan|last1=Sabbagh|first2=Peter|last2=Walker|date=22 October 2018|website=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/uk-politics-45946284/theresa-may-on-next-steps-in-uk-eu-brexit-negotiations|title=May on Brexit: Four steps we need to take|website=BBC News}} On 22 October, Reuters reported that EU sources had told them the EU was "looking at ways to promise Britain a customs deal that could stretch Brussels’ Brexit red lines but might break a deadlock over the Irish border."{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-jigsaw/eu-eyes-brexit-customs-deal-to-break-irish-deadlock-sources-idUSKCN1MW29B|title=EU eyes Brexit customs deal to break Irish deadlock: sources|first=Alastair|last=Macdonald|website=Reuters.com}} On 23 October, EU sources informed the Irish [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTE]] news agency that the EU had made another concession and agreed to a separate treaty ensuring a "UK-wide" customs union which is not "Northern Ireland-only."{{cite web|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/brexit/2018/1023/1006113-brexit/|title=EU may offer British PM a UK-wide customs union|first=Tony|last=Connelly|date=23 October 2018|publisher=RTE}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/10/23/brexit-latest-amber-rudd-warns-trying-oust-theresa-may-would/|title=Brexit latest: EU 'to offer Theresa May UK-wide customs union' to solve Irish backstop - live news updates|first1=Asa|last1=Bennett|first2=James|last2=Rothwell|date=23 October 2018|website=Telegraph.co.uk}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-sterling-open/sterling-rallies-on-report-eu-may-offer-uk-wide-customs-union-idUSKCN1MX0ZW|title=Sterling briefly boosted by hopes EU will offer UK-wide customs union|publisher=Reutuers|date=23 October 2018|accessdate=23 October 2018}} This customs union proposal, which May claimed would further preserve the 1998 [[Good Friday Agreement]] which resulted in the implementation of the [[Northern Ireland peace process]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-45953062|title=Reality Check: Back to the backstop|first=Chris|last=Morris|date=23 October 2018|website=Bbc.com}} was one of the four steps which the British Prime Minister proposed for breaking the Irish border impasse. When asked if this offer by the EU guaranteed a trade deal, May's spokesman stated that more needs to be done and that "any circumstance in which Northern Ireland could be in a separate customs territory to the UK is unacceptable."{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-nireland/uk-says-northern-ireland-can-not-be-in-separate-customs-territory-post-brexit-idUSKCN1MX2B4|title=Sterling briefly boosted by hopes EU will offer UK-wide customs union|publisher=Reutuers|date=23 October 2018|accessdate=23 October 2018}} ''The Business Times'' reported that May was now optimistic that the negotiations for the trade deal would be wrapped up by the end of November.{{cite web|url=https://www.businesstimes.com.sg/government-economy/uk-optimistic-an-unloved-brexit-deal-will-be-negotiated-by-end-nov|title=UK optimistic an unloved Brexit deal will be negotiated by end-Nov|first=Neil|last=Behrmann|website=Businessties.com.sg}} A spokesperson for [[10 Downing Street]] also denied media reports that her Cabinet has been engaged in a "row" over her proposal to end the impasse over the Irish border and that there was merely an "impassioned" agreement that there should be a guarantee of no indefinite extension of the customs union.{{cite web|url=https://www.gulf-times.com/story/610476/No-10-denies-Cabinet-row-over-Brexit-backstop|title=No 10 denies Cabinet row over Brexit backstop|date=23 October 2018|website=Gulf-times.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/oct/23/no-10-denies-cabinet-row-over-brexit-backstop|title=Stormy cabinet meeting increases pressure on May over backstop|first=Dan|last=Sabbagh|date=23 October 2018|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}} On October 24, May confirmed to reporters that there was now a proposal to extend the transition period "by a matter of months." However, May also stated that this proposal "is not expected to be used."{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/1035645/brexit-news-latest-update-theresa-may-EU-transition|title=Brexit LIVE: May's ‘EMOTIONAL’ plea for Tory unity against EU: ‘It is ALWAYS tough'|first=Joe|last=Duggan|date=24 October 2018|website=Express.co.uk}} Leaked papers also revealed that May wanted an agreement from her Cabinet on the next phase of negotiations by the following week and that the proposal was at best a one-year extension of the transition period.{{cite web|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/brexit-transition-period-could-last-for-years-cabinet-warned-rk6qrjdj8|title=Ministers’ anger as May plans to force Brexit deal through|first=Sam Coates, Deputy Political Editor |last=Oliver Wright, Policy Editor|date=24 October 2018|website=Thetimes.co.uk}} Tusk afterwards stated "if the UK decided that such an extension would be helpful to reach a deal, I am sure that the leaders would be ready to consider it positively.” Tusk also stated that the proposal, which May only considers to be an option if needed, was originally brought up May during discussions at the October EU Summit.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/oct/24/theresa-may-first-raise-option-brexit-transition-period-extension-eu|title=May was first to raise option of transition extension, says EU|first=Daniel|last=Boffey|date=24 October 2018|website=the Guardian}} The prevention of an indefinite customs union and assurance from the EU that it an extension would only be an option were two of the four steps which May cited to the end Irish border impasse as well.
