On 31 October, a letter dated 24 October was published revealed that Raab stated to at least one lawmaker that a trade deal would be finalized by the European Union by 21 November and that the end of negotiations was now "firmly in sight"{{cite web|url=http://news.trust.org/item/20181031154215-h446r/|title=Brexit deal could be done by Nov. 21, UK's Raab says|first=Thomson Reuters|last=Foundation|website=News.trust.org}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-31/u-k-expects-brexit-deal-with-eu-by-nov-21-dominic-raab-says?srnd=markets-vp|title=Bloomberg - Are you a robot?|website=Bloomberg.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}} According to Raab, the Prime Minister's four points regarding Northern Ireland were the only issues that still needed to be resolved by this point in time. === November === On 8 November 2018, it was announced that the EU had made concessions and offered a "level playing field" post-Brexit trade deal if Britain were to agree to the backstop.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-backstop/eu-wants-brexit-britain-to-stick-to-aid-environment-rights-rules-sources-idUSKCN1ND0YR|title=EU wants Brexit Britain to stick to aid, environment, rights rules...|first=Gabriela|last=Baczynska|website=Reuters.com}} In a press conference, Foreign Secretary [[Jeremy Hunt]] stated that he was "optimistic" that the planned November EU special summit which had been cancelled at the October summit would now take place before the end of November.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/11/08/brexit-latest-david-davis-urges-mps-reject-theresa-mays-deal/|title=Brexit latest: Ministers play down imminent deal as reports suggest it could be done on Monday|first1=Asa|last1=Bennett|first2=James|last2=Crisp|date=8 November 2018|website=Telegraph.co.uk}} It was acknowledged differences still remained over the lifespan of this new offer. On 12 November, Barnier stated that the Brexit deal was almost ready, but still needed political endorsement.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/19529d88-e67a-11e8-8a85-04b8afea6ea3|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}}[https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2018-11-12/eus-barnier-said-brexit-treaty-text-almost-ready-ft] {{dead link|date=November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/11/12/brexit-latest-senior-cabinet-members-brand-pms-plan-worrying/|title=Downing Street says reports of a Brexit deal should be 'taken with a bucket of salt'|first1=James|last1=Rothwell|first2=Asa|last2=Bennett|date=12 November 2018|website=Telegraph.co.uk}} Barnier also claimed that the text would be presented to May's Cabinet on 13 November.{{cite web|url=https://luxtimes.lu/european-union/35588-barnier-says-treaty-text-almost-ready|title=Barnier says treaty text almost ready|website=Luxtimes.lu}} However, the Prime Minister's office denied that May was ready to accept the EU's latest offer. May later delivered a televised speech where she declared that "the negotiations for our departure are now in the endgame" and insisted that she still will not accept a trade deal which hampers Britain's border and economic sovereignty.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/19529d88-e67a-11e8-8a85-04b8afea6ea3|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/1044442/brexit-news-brexit-deal-trade-asia-pacific-theresa-may|title=BREXIT BOMBSHELL: Confident Theresa May REVEALS first location for ‘Brexit trade mission’|first=Katie|last=Harris|date=13 November 2018|website=Express.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2018}} On 13 November 2018, the UK government and EU agreed on the text of the proposed withdrawal agreement.{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/ee55d6e8-e761-11e8-8a85-04b8afea6ea3|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|accessdate=14 November 2018}} On 14 November 2018, following a five-hour Cabinet meeting, May announced that her Cabinet approved the draft agreement.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46215930|title=Cabinet backs draft Brexit agreement|date=14 November 2018|accessdate=14 November 2018|website=Bbc.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/brexit-deal-latest-theresa-mays-cabinet-backs-eu-divorce-deal-a3990241.html|title=PM's Cabinet backs Brexit divorce deal|website=standard.co.uk|accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/14/world/europe/uk-cabinet-may-brexit.html|title=U.K. Cabinet Backs Theresa May’s Brexit Plan|website=Nytimes.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}} On 15 November 2018, Tusk stated that a new summit will be on 25 November 2018 for EU and that a meeting to discuss preparations for this summit would be held on 20 November.{{cite web|last=Taylor |first=Paul |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/donald-tusk-confirms-november-25-brexit-summit-barnier-uk/ |title=Donald Tusk confirms November 25 Brexit summit |work=Politico.eu |date=15 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On 17 November 2018 May wrote in [[The Sun (British newspaper)|''The Sun'']] that the deal will end both free movement of people and [[European Court of Justice|ECJ]] rule over Britain, and also protect millions of British jobs.{{cn|date=December 2018}} She stated that the November EU summit would go ahead as scheduled. On 18 November, May told ''[[Sky News]]'' that she would attend a meeting in Brussels during the next week.{{cite news|url=https://news.sky.com/story/recap-theresa-may-and-jeremy-corbyn-quizzed-on-sky-news-at-crunch-brexit-moment-11557153?utm_medium=referral&utm_source=t.co |title=Recap: Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn quizzed on Brexit agreement |work=Sky News |date= |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/live/2018/nov/18/theresa-may-brexit-jeremy-corbyn-eu-live?page=with:block-5bf13374e4b07e5fcd49cffa#block-5bf13374e4b07e5fcd49cffa |title=Theresa May to visit Brussels this week as she defends Brexit deal |work=The Guardian |date=18 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On 19 November 2018, EU ministers endorsed the draft agreement.{{cite news|url=https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/eu-ministers-agree-terms-of-painful-brexit-divorce |title=EU ministers agree terms of 'painful' Brexit divorce |work=The Straits Times |date=19 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1446701/eu-ministers-agree-on-terms-of-painful-brexit-divorce |title=EU ministers agree on terms of 'painful' Brexit divorce |work=Dawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://the-japan-news.com/news/article/0005360169 |title=EU ministers agree on terms of 'painful' Brexit |work=The Japan News |date=20 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2018/11/20/no-better-brexit-deal-available-eu-ministers-tell-britain/ |title=No better Brexit deal available, EU ministers tell Britain |work=Theborneopost.com |date=20 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} The same day, the deal was endorsed by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI).{{cite web|url=https://www.france24.com/en/20181119-may-wins-business-support-draft-brexit-deal |title=Flash - May wins business support for draft Brexit deal |work=France 24 |date=19 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/pm-may-wins-business-support-for-draft-brexit-deal-10948078 |title=PM May wins business support for draft Brexit deal |publisher=Channel News Asia |date=20 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On 20 November 2018, the deal won the endorsement of the Bank of England.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2018/nov/20/nissan-shares-carlos-ghosn-arrest-bank-of-england-mark-carney-brexit-business-live |title=Stocks slide and oil tumbles as market selloff gathers pace – as it happened |work=The Guardian |date=20 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On November 21, May traveled to Brussels to hold a meeting with European Commission president [[Jean-Claude Juncker]].https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46284310 and the European Commission released a statement The Commission released a statement that stated that "very good progress" had been made during this meeting. Juncker also cancelled a planned two-day trip to the Canary Islands in order to work with "the many important events taking place at the moment." Commission Vice-President [[Valdis Dombrovskis]] stated that the "sherpas" - officials tasked with doing the detailed work ahead of summits - are scheduled to meet on 23 November to work on the final texts of the withdrawal agreement and the future relationship. On 22 November, European Council President Donald Tusk announced the European Commission's approval of the draft agreement, thus paving the way for the summit which concerns the European Council vote.{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/uk-eu-agree-draft-text-on-future-relations-after-brexit/4669320.html |title=UK, EU Agree Draft Text on Future Relations after Brexit |work=Voanews.com |date=22 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} Tusk also sent a political declaration regarding future EU relations with Britain to the EU27 states and called on their ruling governments to draft it.[https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2018/11/22/draft-political-declaration-setting-out-the-framework-for-the-future-relationship-between-the-eu-and-the-uk-and-article-132-of-the-draft-withdrawal-agreement/ Draft Political Declaration setting out the Framework for the Future Relationship between the EU and the UK] European Council, 22 November 2018 On 22 November, Spanish Prime Minister [[Pedro Sánchez (politician)|Pedro Sánchez]] tweeted, following a phone conversation with May over Gibraltar at Juncker's encouragment, that Britain and Spain still remained "far apart."[https://www.itv.com/news/2018-11-23/spain-gibraltar-brexit-theresa-may-pedro-sanchez/ Why Spain is unhappy about the Brexit deal for Gibraltar] ITV, 22 November 2018 Nevertheless, May stated that she was still "confident" that she and Sánchez "will be able to agree a deal that delivers for the whole UK family, including Gibraltar." On 23 November 2018, the sherpas met, though the dispute with Spain over [[Disputed status of Gibraltar|the issue of Gibraltar]] ensured that May's meeting with Juncker on 24 November will involve resolving the issue in person.{{cite web|last=Baczynska |first=Gabriela |url=https://www.thegazette.com/subject/news/nation-and-world/eu-struggles-to-agree-on-gibraltar-before-brexit-summit-20181123 |title=EU struggles to agree on Gibraltar before Brexit summit |work=The Gazette |date=23 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} Despite new threats from Sánchez of a veto to the trade deal, it has also been acknowledged, including by Spanish Foreign Minister Josep Borrell, that Spain will have no such power at 25 November summit and that any objection at this summit would merely be a sign of EU disunity. It was also acknowledged that Spain's main dispute with Britain was not Gibraltar's departure from the EU with Britain or future trade deals with Britain, but rather that Britain agree to exclude Gibraltar in future negotiations not related to the Gibraltar dispute. The same day, the sherpas agreed a third Brexit document concerning level playing fields with regards to competition with British companies and use of UK fisheries.{{cite web|last=Taylor |first=Paul |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-produces-third-brexit-deal-document/ |title=Third EU Brexit document focuses on fair competition, fisheries |work=Politico.eu |date=23 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On 24 November, Tusk announced that an agreement had been brokered between Britain and Spain and over the Gibraltar dispute and that the dispute will not cancel the upcoming summit.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2018/11/24/brexit-latest-news-deal-shows-leave-winning-would-disastrous/ |title=Brexit latest news: Britain accused of caving in over Gibraltar - live updates |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=25 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-24/brexit-spat-with-spain-appears-to-ease-as-eu-says-summit-closer |title=Are you a robot? |work=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/europe/189446-181124-europe-heads-off-gibraltar-spat-to-save-brexit-summit |title=Europe heads off Gibraltar spat to save Brexit summit |publisher=I24news.tv |date=24 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} Sánchez confirmed this and also stated that Spain would vote yes on the withdrawal agreement.{{cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/brexit/2018/1124/1013054-brexit-eu/ |title=Gibraltar deal clears way for Sunday Brexit summit |work=Rte.ie |date=24 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On 25 November 2018, all of the leaders of the EU27 nations endorsed the Brexit deal at the summit.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-46334649 |title=EU leaders agree UK's Brexit deal at Brussels summit |work=BBC News |date=25 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|last=McKenzie |first=Sheena |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/11/25/europe/brexit-brussels-summit-gbr-intl/index.html |title=Brexit: EU leaders endorse deal at Brussels summit |work=CNN |date=25 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/27-eu-leaders-approve-brexit-deal-with-britain-says-tusk-1953055 |title=European Union Leaders Seal Brexit Deal, Ask Britons To Back Theresa May |work=Ndtv.com |date=25 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/european-union-has-approved-a-brexit-deal-with-britain/news-story/d8fc2c16348282260a56906609f4b8a9 |title=European Union has approved a Brexit deal with Britain |work=News.com.au |date=26 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}} On November 26, May announced that the Parliament vote on the deal will be held on 11 December 2018.https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-update-theresa-may-deal-vote-date-parliament-commons-jeremy-corbyn-debate-a8651661.htmlhttps://www.voanews.com/a/british-lawmakers-warn-they-will-vote-against-brexit-deal/4672952.html US President Donald Trump has objected to the deal. ==Detailed history of negotiations== On 28 June 2016, five days after the referendum, Chancellor of Germany [[Angela Merkel]] announced to the German parliament the forthcoming EU negotiation position: the UK could only remain in the [[European Single Market]] (ESM) if the UK accepted EU migrants. There would be no [[wiktionary:Cherry picking|cherrypicking]] of the ESM's four conditions (free movement of goods, capital, services and labour). While she expected the UK to remain an important NATO partner, the EU's priority was unity and self-preservation. She warned the UK not to delude itself.{{cite news |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article156631505/Mit-Merkel-wird-es-kein-Rosinenpicken-fuer-die-Briten-geben.html |title=Brexit-Bundestagsdebatte: Mit Merkel wird es kein Rosinenpicken für die Briten geben |trans-title=Brexit parliamentary debate: With Merkel there will be no cherrypicking for the British |newspaper=[[Die Welt]] |language=de |date=28 June 2016 |accessdate=14 May 2017}} The next day, Tusk confirmed that the UK would not be allowed access to the ESM unless they accepted its four freedoms of movement for goods, capital, services, and people.{{cite news |last=Heffer |first=Greg |date=29 June 2016 |title='It's not single market à la carte' Donald Tusk tells UK it's Free Movement or Nothing |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/684528/Brexit-Donald-Tusk-Britain-free-movement-access-EU-single-market-David-Cameron |newspaper=Daily Express |access-date=1 July 2016}} In contrast, at her October 2016 party conference, Prime Minister Theresa May emphasised that ending the jurisdiction of EU law and free movement from Europe were priorities. She wished "to give British companies the maximum freedom to trade with and operate in the Single Market – and let European businesses do the same here", but not at the expense of losing sovereignty.{{cite news |date=2 October 2016 |title=Theresa May – her full Brexit speech to Conservative conference |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/theresa-may-conference-speech-article-50-brexit-eu-a7341926.html |newspaper=The Independent |access-date=14 May 2017}}{{cite news |last=Mason |first=Rowena |date=5 October 2016 |title=Theresa May's Conservative party conference speech – key points analysed |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/05/mays-conservative-party-conference-speech-key-points-analysed |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=14 May 2017}} In November 2016, May proposed that Britain and the other EU countries mutually guarantee the residency rights of the 3.3 million EU immigrants in Britain and those of the 1.2 million British citizens living on the Continent, in order to exclude their fates being bargained during Brexit negotiations.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/22/british-expats-set-granted-right-carry-living-eu-theresa-mays |title=British expats set to be granted right to carry on living in EU with Theresa May 'close to reciprocal rights deal' |last=Hope |first=Christopher |date=23 November 2016|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=18 January 2017}} Despite initial approval from a majority of EU states, May's proposal was blocked by European Council President Tusk and German Chancellor Merkel.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/11/29/donald-tusk-accuses-british-voters-backed-brexit-creating-anxiety/ |title=Angela Merkel says 'nein' to Theresa May's calls for early deal on rights of EU migrants and British ex-pats |last=Swinford |first=Steven |date=29 November 2016|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=18 January 2017}} In January 2017, the Prime Minister presented 12 negotiating objectives and confirmed that the UK government would not seek permanent [[British membership of the European Economic Area|single market membership]]. The European Parliament's lead negotiator [[Guy Verhofstadt]] responded that there could be no "cherry-picking" by the UK in the talks.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38641208 |title=Brexit: UK to leave single market, says Theresa May |last=Kuenssberg |first=Laura |date=17 January 2017 |website=BBC News |access-date=14 May 2017}} The statutory period for negotiation began on 29 March 2017, when the letter notifying withdrawal, signed by the British Prime Minister, was handed to the president of the European Council. The letter called for a "deep and special relationship" between the UK and the EU, and warned that failure to reach an agreement would result in EU-UK trade under World Trade Organisation terms, and a weakening of the UK's cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism. The letter suggested prioritising an early deal on the rights of EU citizens in the UK and vice versa. In the letter, the Prime Minister reasoned that, as the EU leaders did not wish "cherry picking" of the ESM, the UK would not seek to remain within the ESM. Instead, the UK would seek a free trade agreement with the EU.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39431070 |date=29 March 2017 |website=BBC News |title=Brexit: The UK's letter triggering Article 50|access-date=15 May 2017}} In response, Merkel insisted that the EU would not discuss future cooperation without first settling the divorce, Verhofstadt referred to the letter as "blackmail" with regard to the point on security and terrorism, and EU Commission president [[Jean-Claude Juncker]] said the UK's decision to quit the block was a "choice they will regret one day".{{cite news |last=Asthana |first=Anushka |date=30 March 2017 |title=Don't blackmail us over security, EU warns May |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/29/brexit-eu-condemns-mays-blackmail-over-security-cooperation |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=15 May 2017}} On 29 April 2017, immediately after the first round of French presidential elections, the EU27 heads of state accepted, without discussion,{{cite news |last=Boffey |first=Daniel |date=29 April 2017 |title=EU leaders agree on tough stance at special Brexit summit |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/apr/29/eu-leaders-set-to-take-tough-stance-in-special-brexit-summit |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=14 May 2017}} negotiating guidelines prepared by the [[President of the European Council]].{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2017/04/29-euco-brexit-guidelines/ |last= |first= |date=29 April 2017 |website=Council of the European Union |title=European Council (Art. 50) guidelines for Brexit negotiations |access-date=14 April 2017}} The guidelines take the view that Article 50 permits a two-phased negotiation, whereby the UK first needs to agree to a financial commitment and to lifelong benefits for EU citizens in Britain, before the EU27 will entertain negotiations on a future relationship.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/29/eu-brexit-guidelines-document-really-means/ |title=EU Brexit guidelines: What's in the document, and what it really means |last=Foster |first=Peter |date=29 April 2017|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=14 May 2017}} In the requested first phase of the withdrawal negotiation, the EU27 negotiators demand the UK pay a "divorce bill", initially estimated as amounting up to £52bn and then, after additional financial demands from Germany, France, and Poland, amounting to £92bn.{{cite web |last=Worstall |first=Tim |date=3 May 2017 |title=It Is To Laugh At Their Mistake – EU's Brexit Bill Claim Now At €100 Billion |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2017/05/03/it-is-to-laugh-at-their-mistake-eus-brexit-bill-claim-now-at-e100-billion/2/#61adde837b74 |website=Forbes |access-date=15 May 2017}} Nevertheless, a report of the [[European Union Committee]] of the House of Lords published on 4 March 2017 states that if there is no post-Brexit deal at the end of the two-year negotiating period, the UK could withdraw without payment.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-39154218 |title=Brexit: UK 'not obliged' to pay divorce bill say peers |date=4 March 2017 |website=BBC News |access-date=30 August 2018}} Similarly, the Prime Minister insisted to EU Commission President Juncker that talks about the future UK-EU relationship should start early and that Britain did not owe any money to the EU under the current treaties.{{cite news |last=Roberts |first=Dan |date=1 May 2017 |title=May dismisses reports of frosty dinner with EU chief as 'Brussels gossip' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/01/jean-claude-juncker-to-theresa-may-on-brexit-im-10-times-more-sceptical-than-i-was-before |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=15 May 2017}} On the EU27 side, unflattering details of a four-way meeting between Prime Minister Theresa May, Brexit Minister David Davis, EU Commission President Juncker and his chief-of-staff [[Martin Selmayr]] were leaked to the German newspaper ''Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung'', presumably by Martin Selmayr.{{cite news |last=Bush |first=Stephen |date=2 May 2017 |title=Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker's dinner leaked because no-one thinks Brexit will work |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/staggers/2017/05/theresa-may-and-jean-claude-junckers-dinner-leaked-because-no-one-thinks |newspaper=New Statesman |access-date=15 May 2017}} According to the leaked description, Juncker claimed that Theresa May was "living in another galaxy" when suggesting that British and EU migrant rights could be rapidly negotiated and agreed in the course of June 2017. German Chancellor Angela Merkel concurred the next day by stating that there were "illusions" on the British side. A few days later, Juncker disclaimed responsibility and called the leak a mistake, ''Der Spiegel'' magazine reported that Angela Merkel was annoyed with Juncker for the leak, while European Council President Tusk admonished participants to use discretion during the negotiations.{{cite web |title=Juncker's jibes continue after Tusk calls for calm |quote=In order to succeed we need discretion, moderation and a maximum of goodwill. |last=Stone |first=Mark |url=http://news.sky.com/story/tusk-warns-over-brexit-emotions-as-juncker-takes-another-swipe-10864632 |website=Sky News |date=6 May 2017 |accessdate=15 May 2017}} The background for German nervousness allegedly is the possibility that Britain may veto EU budget increases, which for example in the immediate term amount to 4 billion euros. A continued British veto would have far-reaching consequences and "will hurt us" according to German MEP Jens Geier.{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/angela-merkel-veraergert-ueber-jean-claude-juncker-nach-brexit-dinner-a-1146299.html |title= Treffen mit May: Merkel verärgert über Juncker nach Brexit-Dinner |trans-title= Meeting with May: Merkel annoyed with Juncker after Brexit dinner |newspaper=[[Der Spiegel]] |language=de |date=6 May 2017 |accessdate=15 May 2017}} On 22 May 2017, the European Council authorised its negotiators to start the Brexit talks and it adopted its negotiating directives.{{cite web |url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2017/05/22-brexit-negotiating-directives/ |title=Council (Art 50) authorises the start of Brexit talks and adopts negotiating directives |website=European Council}} The first day of talks took place on 19 June, where Davis and Barnier agreed to prioritise the question of residency rights, while Davis conceded that a discussion of the Northern Irish border would have to await future trade agreements.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/19/uk-caves-in-to-eu-demand-to-agree-divorce-bill-before-trade-talks |title=Brexit: UK caves in to EU demand to agree divorce bill before trade talks |date=19 June 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=20 June 2017}} On 22 June 2017, Prime Minister May guaranteed, at a European Council meeting in [[City of Brussels|Brussels]], that no EU citizen living legally in the UK would be forced to leave, and she offered that any EU citizen living in the UK for more than 5 years until an unspecified deadline between March 2017 and March 2019 would enjoy the same rights as a UK citizen, conditional on the EU providing the same offer to British expatriates living in the EU. The EU leaders did not immediately reciprocate the offer, with Council President Tusk objecting that the European Council is not a forum for the Brexit negotiations, and Commission president Juncker stating "I'm not negotiating here."{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/22/donald-tusk-john-lennon-eu-summit-uk-britain-brexit |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |title=Donald Tusk echoes John Lennon to suggest UK could stay in EU |first=Daniel |last=Boffey |date=22 June 2017 |accessdate=23 June 2017}} The Prime Minister detailed her residency proposals in the House of Commons on 26 June 2017, but drew no concessions from EU negotiators,{{cite news |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/europe/article/2017/06/27/brexit-les-expatries-premier-bras-de-fer-entre-londres-et-bruxelles_5151696_3214.html |newspaper=[[Le Monde]] |location=Paris |language=fr |title=Brexit: les expatriés, premier bras de fer entre Londres et Bruxelles |trans-title=Brexit: Expatriates, the first arm-wrestling match between London and Brussels |first=Eric |last=Abert |date=27 June 2017 |accessdate=27 June 2017}} who had declined to expedite agreement on expatriates by the end of June 2017, and who are hoping for European courts to continue to have jurisdiction in the UK with regards to EU citizens, according to their negotiation aims published in May 2017.{{cite news |url=https://www.nzz.ch/international/brexit-verhandlungen-london-will-eu-buerger-in-grossbritannien-halten-ld.1302924 |title=Brexit-Verhandlungen: London will EU-Bürger in Grossbritannien halten |trans-title=Brexit negotiations: London wants to keep EU citizens in Britain |newspaper=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]] |language=de |date=26 June 2017 |accessdate=27 June 2017}}{{cite news |title=Reality Check: Britain and EU at odds over citizens' rights |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40413041 |website=BBC News |date=27 June 2017 |accessdate=27 June 2017}} The second round of negotiations began in Brussels in mid-July 2017. It is considered the beginning of substantial negotiations, with 98 UK negotiators and 45 EU27 negotiators.{{cite web |url=https://www.pressreader.com/uk/the-scotsman/20170718/281625305353947 |newspaper=[[The Scotsman]]|title=EU hands Britain a two-month deadline on Brexit talks |first=Paris |last=Gourtsoyannis |date=18 July 2017 |accessdate=19 July 2017}} Progress is being made on the Northern Irish border question, whereas UK negotiators have requested a detailed breakdown of the "divorce bill" demand estimated at 65 billion euros, while the EU negotiators criticise the UK's citizenship rights offer.{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=20 July 2017 |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/eu-and-uk-singing-off-same-hymn-sheet-on-northern-ireland-1.3160534 |accessdate=20 July 2017 |title=EU and UK 'singing off same hymn sheet' on Northern Ireland}} At the concluding press conference, David Davis did not commit to a net payment by the UK to the EU with regards to the requested divorce bill, while Michel Barnier explained that he would not compromise on his demand for the European Court of Justice to have continuing jurisdiction over the rights of EU citizens living in the UK after Brexit,{{cite news |url=https://www.nzz.ch/international/zweite-verhandlungsrunde-in-bruessel-london-bleibt-zu-brexit-rechnung-unverbindlich-ld.1307012 |title=Zweite Verhandlungsrunde in Brüssel: London bleibt zu Brexit-Rechnung unverbindlich |trans-title=Second round of negotiations in Brussels: London remains non-committal to Brexit bill |newspaper=Neue Zürcher Zeitung |language=de |first=Niklus |last=Nuspliger |date=20 July 2017 |accessdate=21 July 2017}} rejecting the compromise proposal of a new international body made up of British and EU judges.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-40662740 |title=Brexit: UK and EU at odds over 'exit bill' |website=BBC News |date=21 July 2017 |access-date=21 July 2017}} On 16 August 2017, the British government disclosed the first of several papers detailing British ambitions following Brexit, discussing trade and customs arrangements.{{cite news |url=https://www.joc.com/international-logistics/brexit-customs-proposal-short-details-say-uk-forwarders_20170816.html |title=UK forwarders: Brexit customs proposal short on details |date=16 August 2017 |newspaper=[[The Journal of Commerce]] |accessdate=9 December 2017}} On 23 August 2017, Prime Minister Theresa May announced that Britain will leave the EU Court of Justice's direct jurisdiction when the Brexit transition period that is planned after March 2019 ends, but that both the British courts and the EU Court of Justice will also keep "half an eye" on each other's rulings afterwards as well.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41012265 |title=PM: UK leaving EU court's jurisdiction |date=23 August 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} One of the UK government's position papers published in August called for no additional restrictions for goods already on the market in the UK and EU.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41089257 |title=Brexit: Jean-Claude Juncker criticises UK's position papers |date=30 August 2017 |website=BBC News |access-date=30 August 2017}} The third round of negotiations began in Brussels on 28 August 2017. The European Commission president Juncker criticised the UK's Brexit negotiations, saying none of the papers provided so far were satisfactory and that there would be no trade negotiations between the EU and UK until the divorce bill was settled. He had previously claimed that the UK's Brexit bill could be £55bn (which Theresa May's government ministers consider unacceptable) and EU Budget Commissioner [[Günther Oettinger]] voiced the view that the UK should make payments until 2023.{{cite news |title=Briten müssen bis 2023 Zahlungen an die EU leisten |trans-title=The British must make payments to the EU until 2023 |newspaper=Die Welt |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/ausland/article168235792/Briten-muessen-bis-2023-Zahlungen-an-die-EU-leisten.html |accessdate=2 September 2017 |first=Christoph| last= Schiltz |date=2 September 2016|language=German}} The ''Irish Times'' explained the disagreement as follows: British negotiators referred to the seven-year [[Multiannual Financial Framework]] (MFF or Maff) for the period 2014-2020 agreed by member states and the EU parliament as a "planning tool" for the next period rather than a legally-binding financial obligation on member states. The British case is that the MFF sets ceilings on spending under various headings and is later radically revised during the annual budget process when real legal obligations on each state arises. This contrasts with the EU Commission's methodology for calculating the UK Brexit bill which involves dividing the MFF into the shares historically agreed by each member state.{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=31 August 2017 |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/huge-gulf-in-negotiations-on-uk-s-brexit-bill-1.3203800 |accessdate=2 September 2017 |title=Huge gulf in negotiations on UK's Brexit bill}} On the Irish border question there was a "breakthrough", with the British side guaranteeing free movement of EU citizens within the [[Common travel area]] constituting Ireland and the United Kingdom.{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=1 September 2017 |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/major-breakthrough-in-irish-strand-of-brexit-talks-1.3205341 |accessdate=2 September 2017 |title=Major breakthrough in Irish strand of Brexit talks}} The BBC's Europe correspondent commented "the British perception of the talks is more positive than the EU's". [[File:VillaDEste.jpg|thumb|300px|The Ambrosetti Forum is held annually in the Villa d'Este on the shores of [[Lake Como]] in Italy.]] At the elite European [[Ambrosetti Forum]] on 2 September 2017, Michel Barnier explained his negotiation aims, in that he would "teach the British people and others what leaving the EU means".{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/michel-barnier-david-davis-brexit-educational-teach-uk-leaving-single-market-negotiations-a7927336.html |title=EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier says he will 'teach the UK what leaving the single market means' |newspaper=The Independent |date=3 September 2017|access-date=3 September 2017}} Although this remark caused controversy in the UK, BBC correspondent Mark Mardell interpreted it in the context of French and Dutch euroscepticism, of the forthcoming German, Austrian and Italian elections, and of the eurosceptic Polish and Hungarian governments.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-41141650 |title=Brexit: A lakeside view of Barnier's tough talk |website=BBC News |date=4 September 2017|access-date=4 September 2017}} In a statement to Parliament on 5 September 2017, David Davis said that "concrete progress" had been made over the summer in areas such as protecting the rights of British expats in the EU to access healthcare and over the future of the Irish border, while significant differences over the "divorce bill" remain.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41155578 |title=Brexit: 'Significant differences' over exit bill says Davis |website=BBC News |date=5 September 2017 |access-date=5 September 2017}} He expected that "the money argument will go on for the full duration of the negotiation. The famous European "nothing is agreed until everything is agreed" will apply here absolutely, as anywhere else".{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/uk/britain-may-hold-out-on-brexit-divorce-cash-until-last-minute-1.3210638 |title=Britain may hold out on Brexit divorce cash until last minute |date=5 September 2017 |accessdate=5 September 2017}} On 6 September 2017, Prime Minister May announced that new immigration controls will be placed on EU nationals when Brexit concludes.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/sep/06/theresa-may-backs-new-eu-immigration-controls-after-brexit-leak |title=Theresa May defends new EU immigration controls after Brexit leak |first1=Heather |last1=Stewart |first2=Peter |last2=Walker |date=6 September 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=9 December 2017}} On 9 September 2017, the EU Commission published several negotiating papers, including "Guiding Principles on the Dialogue for Ireland/Northern Ireland". In it, the EU concedes/declares that it is the responsibility of the UK to propose solutions for the post-Brexit Irish border. The paper envisages that a "unique" solution would be permissible here; in other words, any such exceptional Irish solution should not be seen as a template for post-Brexit relationships with the other EU members on border and customs control matters, for example [[ETIAS]].{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/don-t-use-irish-border-as-test-case-for-eu-uk-border-says-barnier-1.3212836 |title=Don't use Irish Border as test case for EU-UK border, says Barnier |date=7 September 2017 |accessdate=7 September 2017}} At the [[List of European Council meetings#2010–present|European Council meeting]] of 19/20 October 2017, the 27 leaders of the EU states were to decide whether or not to start trade negotiations with the UK. However, David Davis has conceded that so soon after the German elections on 24 September, a German coalition government may not be in place in time for making this decision in October, delaying any European Council decision until their December meeting.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/07/brexit-trade-talks-deadline-slip-december-says-european-parliament/ |title=Brexit trade talks deadline to slip to December, says European Parliament chief |last=Foster |first=Peter |date=7 September 2017|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=7 September 2017}} On 21 September 2017, Prime Minister May, along with her Cabinet,{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-20/may-s-said-to-mull-brexit-bill-offer-to-unlock-talks-in-florence |title=May Clinches Cabinet Support Ahead of Florence Brexit Speech |date=20 September 2017 |website=Bloomberg |accessdate=9 December 2017}} agreed to a transition deal which would inject 20bn euros to the EU budget over a two-year period.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41342580 |title=May 'to offer 20bn euros' transitional deal |date=21 September 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} A cabinet source confirmed to the BBC that May's Cabinet was in fact unity around the Prime Minister's two year transition deal. On 22 September 2017, May announced the details of her Brexit proposal during a speech in [[Florence, Italy]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lUFpahcEOX8 |title=Theresa May's Brexit speech in Florence - watch live Guardian News |date=22 September 2017 |website=YouTube |accessdate=9 December 2017}} In addition to offering 20 billion euros over a two-year transition period and continued acceptance of European immigrants,{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/09/21/europe/uk-may-brexit-speech-florence/index.html |title=UK PM seeks to break Brexit deadlock |first=Laura |last=Smith-Spark |date=22 September 2017 |website=CNN |accessdate=9 December 2017}} she also offered a "bold new security relationship" with the EU which would be "unprecedented in its depth" and to continue to make "an ongoing contribution" to projects considered greatly to the EU and UK's advantage, such as science and security projects.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41355642 |title=Keep EU trade as it is until 2021 - May |date=22 September 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} She also confirmed that the UK would not "stand in the way" of Juncker's proposals for further EU integration. The European Union's Brexit negotiator [[Michel Barnier]] welcomed May's proposal as "constructive," but that it also "must be translated into negotiating positions to make meaningful progress;" Similarly, President of France [[Emmanuel Macron]] was adamant that the EU would not begin negotiations on future EU-UK relationships until "the regulation of European citizens, the financial terms of the exit, and the questions of Ireland" were "clarified" by the UK,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41369600 |title=Brexit: UK needs to clarify issues - Macron |website=BBC News |date=23 September 2017|access-date=23 September 2017}} though he also acknowledged that May did give openings in her speech on two of these three points.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/brexit-cannot-continue-three-main-points-emmanuel-macron-theresa-may-florence-speech-a7962426.html |title=Macron says UK needs to clarify its position on three main Brexit issues before resuming talks |date=22 September 2017 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} Ireland Taoiseach [[Leo Varadkar]] gave May's proposal a "cautious welcome," saying that while it was good of May to reference the Common Travel Area, the Northern Ireland peace process and that both sides in the negotiations do not want any physical structures at the border, more negotiations were needed for clarification.{{cite web |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/politics/2017/0922/906831-politics-varadkar/ |title=Taoiseach gives 'cautious welcome' to May's speech |date=22 September 2017 |website=[[RTÉ News]] |accessdate=9 December 2017}} EU Parliamentary negotiator Guy Verhofstadt responded that "a new registration mechanism for EU citizens going to live and/or work in the UK is out of the question".{{cite news |first=Caroline |last=Mortimer |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-theresa-may-eu-migrant-registration-shot-down-immigration-a7962256.html |title=Brexit: Theresa May's plan for EU migrant registry shot down by Guy Verhofstadt |newspaper=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Limited |date=23 September 2017 |accessdate=25 September 2017}} EU negotiators have stated that an agreement must be reached between Britain and the EU by October 2018 in order to leave time for national parliaments to endorse Brexit.{{cite news |url=http://www.daytondailynews.com/business/the-latest-brexit-chief-welcomes-constructive-speech/eKv8542YSNWjBQCDclPX2M/ |title=The Latest: EU's Brexit chief welcomes 'constructive' speech |date=22 September 2017 |newspaper=[[Dayton Daily News]] |access-date=30 August 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170923002029/http://www.daytondailynews.com/business/the-latest-brexit-chief-welcomes-constructive-speech/eKv8542YSNWjBQCDclPX2M/ |archive-date=23 September 2017}} On the domestic front, Labour Party MP and [[Shadow Home Secretary]] [[Diane Abbott]] announced she would back May's proposed negotiation for the Brexit timetable.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/diane-abbott-backs-theresa-mays-two-year-brexit-transition-plan-11051125 |title=Diane Abbott backs Theresa May's two-year Brexit transition plan |date=24 September 2017 |website=Sky News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} The programme for the fourth round of talks beginning on 25 September arranged for meetings between the "Principals" and for three negotiating groups covering citizens' rights, financial settlement and other separation issues, while Northern Ireland issues would be addressed by the "Coordinators", and governance of the withdrawal agreement would be discussed at technical level. On 16 October, May and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker issued a joint statement agreeing Brexit talks should "accelerate over the months to come" following a dinner meeting in Brussels which both described as "constructive and friendly."{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41642051 |title=PM and EU: Let's speed up Brexit talks |date=17 October 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/theresa-may-and-eu-president-jeanclaude-juncker-promise-to-speed-up-brexit-talks-after-constructive-a3660231.html |title=Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker promise to 'accelerate' Brexit talks after 'constructive and friendly dinner' |date=16 October 2017 |newspaper=[[Evening Standard]] |accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-talks-theresa-may-jean-claude-juncker-brussels-dinner-accelerate-a8003866.html |title=Theresa May and EU president Juncker agree Brexit talks should 'accelerate' |date=16 October 2017 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/16/theresa-may-jean-claude-juncker-pledge-accelerate-brexit-negotiations/ |title=Theresa May and Jean-Claude Juncker pledge to 'accelerate' Brexit talks - but fail to break deadlock |first1=Steven |last1=Swinford |first2=James |last2=Crisp |first3=Peter |last3=Foster |date=16 October 2017|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=9 December 2017}} However, as at a similar dinner earlier in 2017, an unflattering "impressionistic" account of this meeting (between Prime Minister Theresa May, her chief Brexit adviser Olly Robbins, Brexit Minister David Davis, EU Commission President Juncker and the EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier) was published in the same German newspaper ''Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung''. Again, Juncker's chief-of-staff [[Martin Selmayr]] was accused as the source of the publication and of trying to undermine the negotiations. This time however Selmayr denied the accusation, and Chancellor Merkel reportedly denied her involvement.{{cite news |title=Merkel "wütend" über Bericht zu May und Juncker |language=de |trans-title=Merkel "angry" about report on May and Juncker |url=https://derstandard.at/2000066611637/Merkel-wuetend-ueber-Bericht-zu-May-und-Juncker |date=24 October 2017 |accessdate=25 October 2017 |newspaper=[[Der Standard]]}}{{cite news |last=Boffey |first=Daniel |date=24 October 2017 |title=Juncker rejects claim May begged for help at dinner meeting |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/oct/22/mays-ex-policy-chief-claims-juncker-aide-leaked-brexit-dinner-details |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=25 October 2017}} On 17 October, Brexit Secretary David Davis insisted that there will be no deal for a transition phase without EU cooperation and that Brexit will happen regardless, even if there is what one Conservative MP described as "a bridge to nowhere."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/david-davis-no-deal-brexit-uk-transition-period-conservative-theresa-may-eu-relationship-a8005196.html |title=David Davis just significantly cut the odds on a 'no deal' Brexit |date=17 October 2017 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} On 19 October, the first day of the two-day European Council meeting in Brussels, May issued a direct message to approximately three million EU citizens living in Britain, promising she will make it as easy as possible for them to stay after Brexit.{{cite news |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/politics/agreement-on-eu-citizens-in-uk-within-touching-distance-1-4590816 |title=Agreement on EU citizens in UK 'within touching distance' |date=19 October 2017 |newspaper=The Scotsman |accessdate=9 December 2017}} On 20 October, Tusk described media reports of the deadlock in Brexit talks as "exaggerated."{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41684111 |title=Brexit deadlock talk 'exaggerated' - Tusk |date=20 October 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} On 23 October, May announced to the House of Commons that Brexit talks underwent "important progress" during her recent meeting with the European Council and that Britain was now "in touching distance" of a trade deal with EU countries,{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41720244 |title=May hails 'important progress' in EU talks |date=23 October 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/news/politics/654521/brexit-theresa-may-UK-in-touching-distance-of-brussels-deal-jeremy-corbyn-expats |title=Brits on the brink of Brexit: Theresa May says UK 'in touching distance' of Brussels deal |date=23 October 2017|newspaper=[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]] |accessdate=9 December 2017}} while also reiterating that no transition phase will take place following the conclusion of Brexit without a trade deal as well.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2017/oct/23/theresa-may-commons-brexit-statement-leak-saying-may-was-begging-for-help-at-dinner-with-juncker-triggers-fresh-row-with-brussels-politics-live |title=May implies UK will not implement Brexit transition unless trade deal agreed too - Politics live |first=Andrew |last=Sparrow |date=23 October 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=9 December 2017}} The same day, Juncker denied reports by the German media that May had "begged for help" during their recent dinner meeting.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/oct/22/mays-ex-policy-chief-claims-juncker-aide-leaked-brexit-dinner-details |title=Juncker rejects claim May begged for help at dinner meeting |first=Daniel |last=Boffey |date=23 October 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=9 December 2017}} In the wake of the German elections (23 September 2017), as of 10 November, negotiations were still ongoing to form a coalition government between Frau Merkel's CDU, the sister party CSU, the economically liberal FDP and the German Greens; politicians from all three factions published an appeal to reach a coalition agreement (rather than risk new elections), in the interest of Germany forming a "stable anchor" to unite with France and defend the EU and the euro in the current situation.{{cite news |title=Merkel versucht Brückenschlag bei Jamaika-Streitthema Klima |language=de |trans-title=Merkel tries to build bridges in "Jamaica" dispute on climate |url=https://derstandard.at/2000067640939/Merkel-versucht-Brueckenschlag-bei-Jamaika-Streitthema-Klima |date=11 November 2017 |newspaper=Der Standard |accessdate=11 November 2017}} During the sixth round of meetings in Brussels between UK and EU negotiators on 9–10 November, Michel Barnier set the UK a deadline of two weeks to specify a divorce bill that the UK would pay, without which the UK would not be permitted to start trade negotiations in December 2017. Meanwhile, David Davis rejected an EU proposal that Northern Ireland could remain in the EU customs union (thereby creating a customs border "down the [[Irish Sea]]" with [[Great Britain]]).{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-41941414 |title=Brexit bill: Barnier gives UK two weeks to clarify key issues |website=BBC News |date=10 November 2017}} After more than 2 months of a caretaker German government since the German federal elections in September, on 7 December 2017 new elections were averted when the German socialist party under Martin Schulz agreed to negotiate a coalition government with [[Angela Merkel]]'s Christian Democrat party, but on condition that a "United States of Europe" be created by 2025, dismissing those EU member states who were unwilling to participate.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/07/martin-schulz-united-states-of-europe-germany-sdp |title=Martin Schulz wants 'United States of Europe' within eight years |first=Philip |last=Oltermann |date=7 December 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=8 December 2017}} The following day (8 December), the UK and EU negotiators agreed on the principle that "nothing is agreed until everything is agreed" and formally announced to proceed immediately to the next phase of talks on a transition period and future trade relationships.{{cite news |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=8 December 2017 |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/uk/brexit-breakthrough-may-pledges-no-hard-border-as-commission-says-sufficient-progress-made-1.3320030 |accessdate=8 December 2017 |title=Brexit breakthrough: May pledges 'no hard border' as commission says 'sufficient progress' made}}{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-42280487 |title=Brexit deal: Theresa May's agreement with Brussels |last=Morris |first=Chris |date=8 December 2017 |website=BBC News|access-date=11 December 2017}} The EU's negotiating position as at 10 November 2017 was that a future trade relationship between EU and UK should be made conditional upon requirements which would handicap the UK's freedom to negotiate free trade deals with the rest of the world; and that no free trade deal can be agreed in parallel with the Article 50 withdrawal agreement because each of the 27 EU countries would be expected to veto it if they would otherwise face competition from the UK on tax, employment conditions, safety regulations and relaxation of restrictions on GM crops; and that the EU would require any transitional deal to be signed as part of a withdrawal agreement before any agreement was in place on the UK's future relationship with the EU, so that existing arrangements would continue to apply during any transitional period, with the Single Market, Customs Union and European Court of Justice having the same roles as at present, and preventing the UK having control of EU immigration during that period or having the right to enter into trade deals with other countries.{{cite web |url=http://brexitcentral.com/meeting-michel-barnier-guy-verhofstadt-ive-concluded-no-deal-will-better-deal/ |title=After meeting Michel Barnier and Guy Verhofstadt, I've concluded that 'no deal' will be better than their deal |website=BrexitCentral |date=10 November 2017 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} == Legality of payments by the UK to the EU == Two different but incompatible legal approaches would be considered for the Brexit. The EU approach is top down while the British approach is bottom-up. This difference of approach raises a serious problem of confidence.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-eu-divorce-bill-payment-michel-barnier-david-davis-backtracking-brussels-a7934296.html |title=Britain is 'backtracking' on its Brexit divorce bill commitments, EU's chief negotiator warns |date=7 September 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=22 September 2017}} From Michel Barnier point of view, what was decided by 28 member states, has to be paid by 28 member states till the end. The issue of payments by the UK to the EU as part of the exit agreement is subject to much conjecture and has been divided into two broad questions. Firstly, whether a leaving state is legally obligated to contribute to the EU budget beyond its membership period or compensate for any financial losses that EU may suffer on account of withdrawal, given that Article 50 does not concern itself with financial ramifications of a withdrawal; and secondly – if the United Kingdom is legally obligated to pay – what should be the due amount. The leaders of France and Germany have both stated that the UK would need to agree terms regarding the departure before discussing future relationships.{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4359418/PM-gathers-Cabinet-ahead-Article-50-triggered.html |title=Security threats, insults and a £50billion divorce bill: Merkel and Hollande warn of painful Brexit as they reject Britain's call for early trade talks – while PM threatens to cut intelligence ties if we get a bad deal as she triggers Article 50 |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=29 March 2017}} This has been reinforced by EU27 guidelines issued to the remaining 27 countries.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/european-union-to-reveal-its-brexit-negotiating-approach-10818836 |title=Brexit EU guidelines: UK told settle divorce bill before talking trade deals |website=Sky News |date=31 March 2017}} The UK has signalled that it may consider paying the EU to attain preferential access to the economic Single Market and may offer to pay liabilities, even if not legally obligated, on a moral and co-operative basis to secure a preferential working relationship with the EU.{{cite news |title=David Davis suggests UK could pay for single market access |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/dec/01/brexit-secretary-suggests-uk-would-consider-paying-for-single-market-access |newspaper=The Guardian |date=1 December 2016 |accessdate=2 April 2017}} The highest reported claim by the EU is around €60 billion (£50 billion{{when|£50 billion|date=December 2018}}). In March 2017 the [[Bruegel (institution)|Bruegel think tank]] estimated that the UK would need to pay at least €25.4 billion, but the method of calculation is debatable and their calculations using seven different methods produced estimates between €30 and €45 billion.{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/economy/uk-s-brexit-bill-likely-to-be-well-under-60bn-says-think-tank-1.3030853 |title= UK's Brexit bill likely to be well under €60bn, says think tank |newspaper=The Irish Times |date=30 March 2017}} However this £50 billion bill includes the United Kingdom's annual EU contribution (approximately £13 billion annually) for the two years from 2020 and 2021 as agreed in the [[Multiannual Financial Framework]] (MFF).{{Citation needed |date=April 2017}} The United Kingdom, in accordance with Article 50 and unless otherwise extended, will cease to be a member of the EU from 29 March 2019 and the MFF does have a provision for "unforeseen circumstances". EU27 is expected to ask the UK to pay its liabilities in euros, including the relocation costs associated with the two EU bodies currently based in London.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/apr/20/eu-toughens-brexit-stance-and-demands-uk-pay-liabilities-in-euros |title=EU toughens Brexit stance and demands UK pay liabilities in euros |first=Daniel |last=Boffey |date=20 April 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}} Speaking on 20 April, Antonio Tajani said that it was too early to quantify the amount the UK would need to pay and that it was not a bill to leave the EU, it was money needed for farmers and small businesses. === House of Lords report === {{Quote box |quote ="27. It may seem intuitive that when the UK leaves the EU, it leaves behind both the responsibilities and benefits of membership. However, this does not take account of the complexity of the UK's participation in the EU, nor of the procedures for agreeing current and future budgets, which involve mutual commitments projected many years into the future. ...33. The range of values in circulation for the UK's potential 'exit bill' indicates that the absolute sum of any posited settlement is hugely speculative. Almost every element is subject to interpretation." |source =HL Paper 125, 4 March 2017, European Union Committee 15th sessional report, ''Brexit and the EU budget '', Chapter 3, ''Potential demands''.[https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201617/ldselect/ldeucom/125/12506.htm#_idTextAnchor024] |align = right |width = 20% }} A March 2017 House of Lords report acknowledges that the EU may claim for (1) part of the current budget (which runs from 2014 to 2020) post March 2019, because it was approved by the UK (2) part of the EU future commitments which amount to €200 billion and (3) a contribution if the UK is to continue with access to some EU programmes.{{cite web |url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-7886 |title=The UK's contribution to the EU budget |website=House of Lords |date=16 March 2017}} The report concluded that the UK had no legal obligation to make "exit" payments to the EU if there was no post Brexit deal.{{cite web |title=Brexit and the EU Budget |url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201617/ldselect/ldeucom/125/125.pdf |website=House of Lords |date=4 March 2017 |accessdate=2 April 2017}} Discussing financial and legal complexities involved in negotiating withdrawal, including settlement of outstanding financial liabilities and division of assets, the report mentions (paragraph 15) that the EU budget is funded by revenue drawn from various sources, governed by the EU's Own Resources Decision (ORD), which was made part of UK law by the [[European Union (Finance) Act 2015]].{{cite web |url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/32/pdfs/ukpgaen_20150032_en.pdf |title=European Union (Finance) Act 2015, Explanatory Notes |website=UK Government}} The revenue includes contributions from import duties and [[VAT]] collected by member states. The report also mentions the EU [[Multiannual Financial Framework]] for controlling the annual expenditure. === Assets and liabilities === The EU has considerable assets including buildings, equipment and financial instruments, and there is a potential claim by the UK for a portion of these assets. [[Boris Johnson]], the UK's [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]], commenting on the Brexit "divorce bill" in May 2017 stated that the valuable EU assets the UK has paid for over the years should be properly valued, and that there were good arguments for including them in the negotiations.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/boris-johnson-says-brussels-should-pay-preposterous-brexit-bill-10875068 |title=Boris Johnson says Brussels should [not] pay 'preposterous' Brexit bill |date=13 May 2017 |website=Sky News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=13 May 2017}} The [[Bank of England]] (BoE) has invested in the [[European Central Bank]] (ECB) amounting to 13.6743%, representing paid up capital of €55.5 billion. The BoE does not participate in any profits (or losses) of the ECB.{{cite web |url=https://www.ecb.europa.eu/ecb/orga/capital/html/index.en.html |title=Capital subscription |website=European Central Bank |date=1 January 2015}} The BoE has also made loans to the ECB. The ECB set up the [[European Financial Stability Facility]] in 2010, which has a borrowing facility of €440bn and in addition used a guarantee from the [[European Commission]] and the [[Budget of the European Union]] as collateral to borrow a further €60bn. The UK withdrawal will affect the ECB. The EU has a pension liability of €64 billion. The UK benefits from a [[UK rebate|rebate]] which reduces its contribution to the [[EU budget]]. The rebate is paid a year in arrears, accordingly the 2019 rebate would be payable in 2020. === Policy paper === The EU drafted a 10-page position document regarding the single bill. This position does not define the final cost of the divorce.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/30/painstaking-detail-brexit-process-revealed-eu-documents |title=Painstaking detail of Brexit process revealed in EU documents |first=Jennifer |last=Rankin |date=30 May 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=23 June 2017}} == UK citizens elsewhere in the EU and other EU citizens in the UK == Concerns have been raised by UK citizens who live in other EU countries, and by citizens from those countries who live in the UK. In May 2017, [[Michel Barnier]] stated: "Currently around 3.2 million EU citizens work and live in the UK, and 1.2 million British citizens work and live in the EU."{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-1236_en.htm |title=Press release – Speech by Michel Barnier at the 7th State of the Union Conference, European University Institute, Florence |last= |first= |date=5 May 2017 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 May 2017}} Issues include rights of movement, citizenship, abode, education, social support and medical treatment, and the payment of pensions; and the extent to which these rights apply to family members.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/may/03/may-expected-to-challenge-right-of-eu-citizens-to-bring-family-to-britain-non-european-spouses-brexit |title=May expected to challenge right of EU citizens to bring family to Britain |last=Travis |first=Alan |date=3 May 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=4 May 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |last2=Roberts |first2=Dan|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} Considerations for UK citizens resident in an EU27 country include their rights to work or live in a different EU27 country.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/joint-technical-note-on-the-comparison-of-eu-uk-positions-on-citizens-rights |title=Joint technical note on the comparison of EU-UK positions on citizens' rights |website=Department for Exiting the European Union |date=20 July 2017 |language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=21 July 2017}} Beyond the 27 EU countries, workers have certain [[Freedom of movement for workers in the European Union|freedom of movement]] rights to/from Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland. "Associate citizenship", suggested by EU27 negotiator Guy Verhofstadt, would allow UK nationals to volunteer individually for EU citizenship, enabling them to continue to work and live on the continent. Jean-Claude Juncker, president of the European Commission, is not opposed to the idea.{{cite web |url=https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Brexit/EU-president-not-opposed-to-associate-citizenship-plan |title=EU president 'not opposed' to associate citizenship plan |website=Connexion France |date=31 March 2017}} Antonio Tajani spoke after a meeting with Theresa May on 20 April 2017, saying "the issue of reciprocal EU citizen rights should be negotiated 'immediately' with a view to getting an agreement by the end of the year." The European Commission published a position paper on "Essential Principles on Citizens' Rights" on 12 June 2017, proposing that current and future family members of European nationals in the UK would keep their rights to settle in their residence country at any time after Britain's withdrawal.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/publications/position-paper-essential-principles-citizens-rights_en |title=Position paper transmitted to the UK: essential principles on citizens' rights |last= |first= |date=12 June 2017 |website=European Commission|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 June 2017}} Speaking in advance of publication of the paper, David Davis described the demands as "ridiculously high".{{Cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/brexit-negotiations-latest-david-davis-eu-demands-citizens-rights-ridiculously-high-european-union-a7762986.html |title=David Davis says EU demands on citizens' rights are 'ridiculously high' |last=Bulman |first=May |date=30 May 2017 |newspaper=The Independent|access-date=22 June 2017 |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB}} The UK government published their policy paper "Safeguarding the position of EU citizens in the UK and UK nationals in the EU" on 26 June.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/safeguarding-the-position-of-eu-citizens-in-the-uk-and-uk-nationals-in-the-eu |title=Safeguarding the position of EU citizens in the UK and UK nationals in the EU |last= |first= |date=26 June 2017 |website=UK Government |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 June 2017}} The policy paper proposed that EU citizens living in Britain will be required to apply for inclusion on a "settled status" register if they wish to remain in the country after Brexit.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jun/26/eu-citizens-living-in-uk-must-apply-for-special-id-card-after-brexit |title=Brexit: EU citizens living in UK will have to join special ID register |last=Travis |first=Alan |date=26 June 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=27 June 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} By the end of September 2017 progress had been made on several of the 60 points which became green, while 13 out of the 60 points remain red. Three points (points #14, #15, and #16 related to monitoring and CJEU) have to be addressed at governance level. Few points remain to be clarified (that is yellow).{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/table_-_citizens_rights.pdf |title=Comparison of EU/UK Positions on Citizens' Rights |date=28 September 2017 |website=European Commission |access-date=30 August 2018}} On this basis European parliament will have to assess if sufficient progress has been made. As of October 2018, UK residents in the EU have not yet had their fates decided on: On 16 October 2018, just before departing for the EU27-UK summit in Brussels, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, speaking to the German parliament, asked "How do we treat the 100,000 British citizens in Germany on the day after Brexit if there is no deal?", without supplying an answer.{{Cite news |url=https://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/merkel-regierungserklaerung-zum-brexit-1.4174193 |title=Merkels vier Minuten für den Brexit [Merkel's four minutes for Brexit] |last=Al-Serori |first=Leila |date=17 October 2018 |newspaper=Sueddeutsche Zeitung |access-date=17 October 2018|language=de|issn=}} === Implications === The general rule for losing EU citizenship is that European citizenship is lost if member state nationality is lost,{{cite web |url=http://www.ilecproject.eu/sites/default/files/GUIDELINES%20INVOLUNTARY%20LOSS%20OF%20EUROPEAN%20CITIZENSHIP%20.pdf |title=Guidelines: Involuntary Loss of European Citizenship |date=2015 |website=European Union |access-date=30 August 2018}} but the automatic loss of EU citizenship as a result of a member state withdrawing from the EU is the subject of debate.{{cite journal |url=http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2324&context=ilj |title=The Withdrawal Clause of the Lisbon Treaty in the Light of EU Citizenship (Between Disintegration and Integration) |last=Rieder |first=Clemens M. |journal=Fordham International Law Journal |volume=37 |issue=1 |date=2013 |access-date=30 August 2018}} The situation of a person acquiring EU citizenship when the UK joined the EU in 1973 compared to a person born in the UK after 1973 and was therefore born into EU citizenship, may differ. It may be necessary for the ECJ to rule on these issues. In a 2017 decision, the ECJ ruled that the parent/s of a child with EU nationality are entitled to rights of residence, even if both non EU citizens.{{cite news |url=http://www.brusselstimes.com/eu-affairs/8212/non-european-parents-of-european-child-have-eu-right-of-residency |title=Non-European parents of European child have EU right of residency |newspaper=Brussels Times |date=11 May 2017}} This may have consequential effects for UK residents who have young children and wish to live in the EU27 territory post Brexit, but this remains to be tested. === Immigration and mobility === Until the UK effectively withdraws from the EU in 2019 or at another agreed date, the current system of free movement of labour between the EU27 and the UK remains in place. The report of the House of Commons [[Exiting the European Union Select Committee|Exiting the European Union Committee]] on ''The Government's negotiating objectives'', published in April 2017,{{cite web |url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201617/cmselect/cmexeu/1125/112502.htm |title=3rd Report – The Government's negotiating objectives: the White Paper (HC 1125) |date=4 April 2017 |website=House of Commons |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=4 April 2017}} proposed (paragraphs 20 and 123) that the future system for EU migration should meet the needs of different sectors of the UK economy, including those employing scientists, bankers, vets, care workers, health service professionals and seasonal agriculture workers. [[Theresa May]], answering press questions on 5 April 2017, commented that the free movement of labour would not end in March 2019; an implementation period of possibly five years would give business and government time to adjust.{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4381026/Don-t-expect-EU-free-movement-end-five-years.html |title=Don't expect EU free movement to end for at least five years, May warns: PM says there will be an 'implementation period' after Britain leaves |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=5 April 2017}} The UK currently charges an annual levy of up to £1,000 for each non-EU citizen employed within the UK.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/uk-visa-sponsorship-employers/immigration-skills-charge |title=UK visa sponsorship for employers: Immigration skills charge |date= |website=UK Government |language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 May 2017}} Proposals are under consideration to increase this 'immigration skills charge' to £2,000 p.a. and to implement a similar levy on EU citizens employed in the UK.{{cite web |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/18/news/economy/foreign-worker-charge-theresa-may/index.html |title=Americans are going to find it much harder to get a job in Britain |website=CNN |date=18 May 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-news-uk-employers-pay-1000-per-eu-skilled-worker-european-immigration-skills-levy-a7521626.html |title=UK employers would have to pay a £1,000-a-year fee per EU skilled worker after Brexit under new government plans |newspaper=The Independent |date=11 January 2017}} According to an unconfirmed newspaper report, a leaked Home Office paper has a proposal that the UK will end the free movement of labour of low-skilled workers immediately after Brexit, focusing on highly skilled EU workers instead.{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/sep/05/leaked-document-reveals-uk-brexit-plan-to-deter-eu-immigrants |title=Leaked document reveals UK Brexit plan to deter EU immigrants |last=Hopkins |first=Nick |date=5 September 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=6 September 2017 |last2=Travis |first2=Alan|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/uk-eu-migrants-brexit-plans-to-cut-back-on-post-brexit-report/ |title=UK plans to cut back on EU migrants post Brexit: report |date=5 September 2017 |website=Politico.eu |access-date=6 September 2017|language=en-US}} The proposal would limit lower-skilled EU migrants' residency permits to a maximum of two years, and the implementation of a new immigration system ending the right to settle in Britain for most European migrants while placing tough restrictions on their rights to bring over family members. Those in "high-skilled occupations" could be given permission to work in the UK for a period of three to five years. ==Immigration== Immigration is one topic requiring partnership between EU and UK, as according to Theresa May, "Mass migration and terrorism are but two examples of the challenges to our shared European interests and values that we can only solve in partnership".{{cite magazine |url=https://blogs.spectator.co.uk/2017/09/theresa-mays-brexit-speech-full-text/ |title=Theresa May's Florence speech on Brexit, full text |date=22 September 2017 |magazine=[[The Spectator]] |accessdate=9 December 2017}} In the context of Brexit, the question of migration might contains two subtopics: on one hand migrations between EU including UK and third countries which might be dealt with at a local level; and on the other hand migration between EU and UK once UK has become a third country which was discussed for the withdrawal agreement. ==European Court of Justice (ECJ)== The concept of [[European Court of Justice]] competence creates complications. Some pro-Brexiteers believe the Court of Justice might be completely removed from the UK landscape. Various other opinions consider that the Court of Justice or some equivalent should be able to rule on remaining issues after Brexit (for instance between a European and a British stakeholder), at least in respect of the TEU ([[Treaty on European Union]]), [[Citizenship of the European Union|European Union citizens]], or access to the [[European Single Market]].{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-eu-ministers-invincible-ignorance-european-court-sir-david-edward-theresa-may-a7656826.html |title='Invincible ignorance' of Theresa May's Brexit-backing ministers condemned by former judge |date=29 March 2017|newspaper=The Independent}} After the 2017 negotiations, in February 2018 the European Commission Draft Withdrawal Agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/draft_withdrawal_agreement.pdf |title=European Commission Draft Withdrawal Agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community |date=28 February 2018 |website=European Commission |access-date=30 August 2018}} consider for instance that: * "The Court of Justice of the European Union shall continue to have jurisdiction for any proceedings brought before it by the United Kingdom or against the United Kingdom before the end of the transition period. That jurisdiction shall extend to all stages of proceedings, including appeal proceedings before the Court of Justice and proceedings before the General Court after a case has been referred back to it." * "The Court of Justice of the European Union shall continue to have jurisdiction to give preliminary rulings on requests from courts and tribunals of the United Kingdom referred to it before the end of the transition period." ==Sectoral issues== Brexit might have impact in various sectors.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/brexit-economy-sterling-currency-investment-cost-impact-business-financial-banks-insurance-retail-a7695486.html |title=Cost of Brexit: The impact on business and the economy so far |date=21 April 2017 |newspaper=The Independent}} Documents setting out how the Brexit will affect parts of the [[British economy]] were set up for the government, "the most comprehensive picture of our economy on this issue" containing "excruciating detail" according to Brexit Secretary David Davis. The ministers were reluctant to [[publish]] them but in November, a vote in Parliament allowed lawmakers to read them under controlled conditions to avoid [[news leak]]s. They were released online on 21 December 2017 but lawmakers were unimpressed: "Most of this could be found on [[Wikipedia]] or with a quick [[Google search]]," said Labour's [[David Lammy]], "these documents [were made] in a couple of weeks.
