They look like copy and paste essay crises."{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-12-20/may-heads-to-poland-to-seek-brexit-ally-after-firing-her-deputy |title=May Lands in Poland to Seek Brexit Ally After Firing Deputy |first=Robert |last=Hutton |date=21 December 2017 |website=Bloomberg}} === Trade === Without a trade agreement in place, UK trade with the EU would be governed by the World Trade Organization's [[Bali Package]]. This would lead to common tariffs and [[non-tariff barriers to trade|non-tariff barriers]] being imposed by the EU27 upon the UK's access to the [[European Single Market]], because the Market is also a [[customs union]]. However, the UK would then have an opportunity to control immigration as well as develop its own trade regulations. The UK is not permitted to hold trade talks until after Brexit is concluded, however the UK can do preparatory work with other countries regarding the UK's future trading relationships; this is not to the liking of some EU27 countries. Before Britain leaves the EU, they may put trade agreements in place with non-EU countries.{{cite report |title=Brexit, Ireland and Northern Ireland |publisher=Constitutional Conundrums |date=2016}} Only the EU can act in areas where it has exclusive competence, such as the customs union and common commercial policy. In those areas Member States may not act independently.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/279629/bis-13-865-balance-of-competences-review-trade-and-investment.pdf |title=Review Of The Balance Of Competences Between The United Kingdom And The European Union |date=May 2013 |website=[[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills]] |access-date=30 August 2018}} The UK can still negotiate its own bilateral investment protection treaties subject to Commission authorization. Strategic controls on military goods are primarily a Member State competence. As a result, Member States themselves negotiate multilateral or bilateral agreements on the strategic aspects of trade in defense goods. The EU27 wish to exclude the UK from sitting in on trade negotiations held by the EU during the period ending March 2019, seeing the UK as a competitor. Theresa May rejected this idea, saying "While we're members of the European Union we would expect our obligations but also our rights to be honored in full."{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.eu/article/trade-talks-for-non-british-eyes-only/ |title=Trade talks: For non-British eyes only? |website=Politico.eu |date=10 April 2017}} ==== Regional foods ==== {{see| List of United Kingdom food and drink products with protected status}} The [[Geographical indications and traditional specialities in the European Union|Geographical indications and traditional specialties in the European Union]], known as protected designation of origin (PDO) is applied internationally via bilateral agreements. Without an agreement with the EU27, UK producers of products such as the [[Cornish Pasty|Cornish pasty]], [[Scotch whisky]] and [[Jersey Royals|Jersey Royal]] potatoes are at risk of being copied. ==== Fisheries ==== The EU27 have stated that UK fish suppliers could lose tariff-free access to the continent unless EU countries have continued access to UK waters after Brexit.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/958c7e28-0f1c-11e7-b030-768954394623 |title=EU fishing fleet urges post-Brexit access to UK seas |newspaper=Financial Times |date=22 March 2017|url-access=subscription}} '''Agriculture''' The Irish agricultural sector is heavily dependent on UK markets for its exports. === Financial services === ==== Banks ==== Investment banks may want to have new or expanded offices up and running inside the EU27 bloc before the UK's departure in March 2019, with [[Frankfurt]] and [[Dublin]] the possible favourites.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-03-21/what-the-biggest-banks-are-planning-as-may-sets-brexit-timing |title=What the biggest banks are planning once Brexit starts |website=Bloomberg |date=21 March 2017}} Ireland's investment arm, IDA Ireland, witnessed an increase in inquiries from London-based financial groups considering to open up on an office in Dublin by the end of 2016, mostly coming from North American companies. In May 2017, JP Morgan became the first major bank to officially choose Dublin to transfer some of its personnel and operations from its London office.{{cite web |url=http://www.the-businessreport.com/article/can-dublin-become-eus-next-finance-hub/ |title=Can Dublin become the EU's next finance hub? |website=The Business Report |date=January 2017 |accessdate=14 July 2017}} ==== Insurance ==== [[Lloyd's of London]] have confirmed that they will open a subsidiary in Brussels, hoping to ensure continuation of their continental business which generates 11% of its premiums.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-39441035 |title=Insurer Lloyd's of London confirms new Brussels subsidiary |website=BBC News |date=30 March 2017}} ==== Asset management companies ==== The situation may be different when it comes to the [[fund management]] industry, as British asset owners, notably UK [[pension fund]]s, often constitute an incommensurate share of total turnover for German, French, Dutch and other [[Continental European]] asset managers. This imbalance could potentially give Britain some negotiating leverage e.g. power of [[retorsion]] in case the EU attempts to impose an abrupt cancellation of the mutually-binding obligations and advantages pertaining to the [[Markets in Financial Instruments Directive 2004]] (''"fund passporting"''). Research conducted by the [[World Pensions & Investments Forum|World Pensions Council (WPC)]] shows that {{quote|"Assets owned by UK pension funds are more than 11 times bigger than those of all German and French pension funds put together […] If need be, at the first hint of threat to the City of London, Her Majesty's Government should be in a position to respond very forcefully."{{cite web |title= Beyond Brexit: Britain, Europe and the Pension Wealth of Nations |url=https://www.academia.edu/26810948/Beyond_Brexit_Britain_Europe_and_the_Pension_Wealth_of_Nations |website=Pensions Age |date=July 2016 |page=44 |accessdate=11 July 2016}} }} ==== Stock exchanges ==== The [[London Stock Exchange]] issued a warning over a proposal by the EU, to allow euro-denominated transactions to be cleared only within the EU [[eurozone]], claiming it would increase business costs by €100bn over 5 years and isolate the euro capital market.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/warning-to-brussels-over-stripping-city-of-euro-clearing-10888828 |title=Warning to Brussels over stripping City of euro clearing |website=Sky News |date=22 May 2017}} === Security === The letter of 29 March 2017 giving the UK's [[United Kingdom invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union|notice of intention to withdraw]] from the EU stated "In security terms a failure to reach agreement would mean our cooperation in the fight against crime and terrorism would be weakened." This was seen by some as a threat.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/29/brexit-eu-condemns-mays-blackmail-over-security-cooperation |title=Don't blackmail us over security, EU warns May |last= |first= |date=30 March 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 April 2017}} On 31 March, [[Boris Johnson]], the UK Foreign Secretary, confirmed that the "UK commitment to EU security is unconditional".{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/mar/30/uk-article-50-letter-european-diplomats-threat-security-cooperation |title=Boris Johnson joins UK attempts to calm Brexit security concerns |last= |first= |date=31 March 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 April 2017}} The call by the United States to other members of [[NATO]] to increase their defence expenditure to the 2% of GDP level coincides in timing with Brexit. The UK is the second largest contributor to NATO defence, one of only five to meet the 2% level and one of only two EU members who have nuclear weapons. The possibility of a new Franco-German partnership to fill the vacuum left by Britain has been raised as a possibility and post Brexit an EU military headquarters, previously vetoed by the UK, may be created.{{cite web |url=http://www.france24.com/en/20170403-france-eu-nato-boost-military-defense-spending-brexit-us-warnings-isolationism |title=EU, French militaries prepare to go it alone after Brexit, US warnings |website=France24 |date=3 April 2017}} The UK is fully committed to NATO. === Academic research === {{Main|Brexit and arrangements for science and technology}} The UK government's negotiating policy when the negotiating period started on 29 March 2017 included remaining at the vanguard of science and innovation, and seeking continued close collaboration with the UK's European partners. == British Overseas Territories and Crown dependencies == In the [[Great Repeal Bill 2016|Great Repeal Bill]] [[white paper]] published on 30 March 2017, the UK government stated "The Government is committed to engaging with the Crown Dependencies, Gibraltar and the other Overseas Territories as we leave the EU."{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/604514/Great_repeal_bill_white_paper_print.pdf |title=Legislating for the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union |website=Department for Exiting the European Union |date=30 March 2017}}{{rp|ch.5}} ===Overseas territories=== [[Robin Walker]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]], a junior minister at the Department for Exiting the European Union, is responsible for managing the relationship between the overseas territories and Parliament in their discussion with the EU27.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/225fe8b6-ed59-11e6-930f-061b01e23655?mhq5j=e1 |title=British overseas territories set out their Brexit priorities |newspaper=Financial Times |accessdate=23 June 2017|url-access=subscription}} ==== Gibraltar ==== {{main|Gibraltar after Brexit}} Brexit raised issues around [[sovereignty]] for [[Gibraltar#Governance|Gibraltar]], the only [[British Overseas Territories|British Overseas Territory]] in the EU.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/apr/02/spain-drops-plan-to-impose-veto-if-scotland-tries-to-join-eu |title=Spain drops plan to impose veto if Scotland tries to join EU |first=Jennifer |last=Rankin |date=2 April 2017|newspaper=The Guardian}} Gibraltarians voted to stay in the European Union by 96%.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/01/world/europe/gibraltar-brexit-spain-britain-european-union.html |title=Spain's Desire for Gibraltar Complicates 'Brexit' Talks With E.U. |first=Stephen |last=Castle |date=1 April 2017|newspaper=The New York Times}} Spain claims sovereignty over Gibraltar; however, in 2002 [[Gibraltar sovereignty referendum, 2002|Gibraltarians voted 99% to keep British sovereignty]]. The EU27 draft guidelines allow Spain a veto over any effect that the Brexit agreement has as regards Gibraltar. The guidelines state: "After the United Kingdom leaves the Union, no agreement between the EU and the United Kingdom may apply to the territory of Gibraltar without the agreement between the Kingdom of Spain and the United Kingdom."{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/story/brexit-guidelines-eu-hands-spain-power-over-gibraltars-future-10819502 |title= Brexit guidelines: EU hands Spain power over Gibraltar's future |website=Sky News |date=31 March 2017}} === Crown dependencies === The [[Crown dependencies]] are neither part of the EU nor of the UK. They have a unique constitutional relationship both with the UK and, as encapsulated in Protocol 3 to the UK's [[Treaty of Accession 1972|Treaty of Accession]], with the EU.{{cite web |url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld201617/ldselect/ldeucom/136/136.pdf |title=Brexit: the Crown Dependencies |website=House of Lords |date=23 March 2017}} They have no voting rights in EU or UK referenda or elections and no international voice, the UK government having the responsibility to act for the dependencies on foreign matters. [[Oliver Heald]] [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] is responsible for managing the relationship between the Islands and Parliament in their discussion with the EU27.{{cite news |url=http://guernseypress.com/news/2017/04/08/protecting-finance-and-legal-sectors-a-priority-for-minister/ |title=Protecting finance and legal sectors a priority for minister |newspaper=Guernsey Press |date=8 April 2017}} ==The "no deal" scenario== If no withdrawal agreement is in place on 30 March 2019 at midnight (European central time) or at 23h on 29 March (British time) (the end of the two-year period under Article 50) the EU Treaties will cease to apply to the UK.{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/headlines/priorities/20160701TST34439/20160707STO36103/brexit-negotiations-deciding-new-eu-uk-relations |title=Brexit negotiations: deciding new EU-UK relations |date=7 July 2016 |website=European Parliament |accessdate=9 December 2017}} It is understood that, should there be "no deal", there will be no transition period and EU law (in particular, the Single Market) will cease to apply to the UK/EU relationship from that date.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-44887513 |title=Reality Check: The EU's 'no deal' preparations |first=Chris |last=Morris |date=19 July 2018 |website=BBC News}} However, the EU would prefer a Brexit with an agreed deal rather than with no deal. Nonetheless, even in the case of a no withdrawal deal, the Commission believes that UK and EU may soon relaunch trade negotiations.{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.eu/article/brexit-negotiation-no-deal-european-commission-publishes-briefing-planning/ |title=European Commission publishes briefing on no-deal Brexit planning |date=19 July 2018 |website=Politico.eu}} ===No deal possibility and likeliness=== A Parliamentary inquiry has concluded that "the possibility of 'no deal' is real enough to justify planning for it. The Government has produced no evidence, either to this inquiry or in its White Paper, to indicate that it is giving the possibility of 'no deal' the level of consideration that it deserves, or is contemplating any serious contingency planning. This is all the more urgent if the Government is serious in its assertion that it will walk away from a 'bad' deal."{{cite web |url=https://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201617/cmselect/cmfaff/1077/107702.htm |title=House of Commons - Article 50 negotiations: Implications of 'no deal' - Foreign Affairs Committee |website=UK Parliament |accessdate=23 June 2017}} The UK government has consistently said that it will aim for the "best possible deal" but that "no deal is better than a bad deal". This position was restated in the Conservative Party manifesto for the 2017 general election.''Conservative and Unionist Party Manifesto 2017''. 18 May 2017. pp35-36. "The negotiations will undoubtedly be tough, and there will be give and take on both sides, but we continue to believe that no deal is better than a bad deal for the UK. But we will enter the negotiations in a spirit of sincere cooperation and committed to getting the best deal for Britain." In July, Michel Barnier said that "a fair deal is better than no deal", because "In the case of Brexit, 'no deal' is a return to a distant past".{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2017/jul/06/frictionless-trade-impossible-if-uk-leaves-eu-single-market-says-barnier |title=Frictionless trade impossible if UK leaves EU single market, says Barnier |last=Rankin |first=Jennifer |date=6 July 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|access-date=7 July 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} According to the French Prime Minister [[Édouard Philippe]], "The more we think the worst should be avoided, the more we think it's not impossible it could eventually happen".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/19/business/europe-brexit-contingencies.html |title=How E.U. Is Getting Ready for Chaos in a Worst-Case Brexit|newspaper=The New York Times |date=19 July 2018}} With the British (UK) white paper, both sides are wondering if the ''no deal scenario'' is more likely rather than possible.{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/18/eu-assault-on-mays-white-paper-heightens-no-deal-brexit-fears |title=EU assault on May's white paper heightens 'no deal' Brexit fears |first=Daniel |last=Boffey |date=18 July 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}} ===No deal adverse consequences=== A "no-deal" Brexit has been described by [[General Council of the Bar]], a lawyers' interest body, as "falling over the cliff-edge".{{cite web |url=http://www.barcouncil.org.uk/media-centre/publications/2017/2017/march/the-brexit-papers-second-edition/ |title=The Brexit Papers: Second Edition |website=General Council of the Bar |accessdate=23 June 2017}} According to the IMF, the no deal Brexit could create economic pain across Europe, with no winner.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jul/19/no-deal-brexit-would-harm-all-european-countries-warns-imf |title=No-deal Brexit would harm EU countries as well as UK, warns IMF |first=Richard |last=Partington |date=19 July 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}} The most affected country would be UK, according to the IMF: the IMF consider that UK and Ireland could lose 4% of their GDP, while close countries such as the Netherlands, Denmark and Belgium could lose 1% of GDP. In September 2017 the BBC reported that there was little evidence of UK government preparations for a "No Deal" scenario: "our government is not behaving like it is really preparing for No Deal – and the EU27 can surely see it."{{cite web |last1=Cook |first1=Chris |title=Will the government really accept 'No Deal' with the EU? |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-41271028 |website=BBC News |date=19 September 2017 |accessdate=21 September 2017}} In her 4 October 2017 speech at the Conservative Party Conference, UK Prime Minister Theresa May repeated her position that "no deal is better than a bad deal" and emphasized that "It is our responsibility as a government to prepare for every eventuality. And let me reassure everyone in this hall – that is exactly what we are doing."{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-theresa-may-speech-conference-no-deal-assurance-tories-a7983071.html |title=Theresa May tried to 'reassure' Tories that she is still prepared to leave EU with no Brexit deal |date=4 October 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} In her 9 October 2017 statement in the House of Commons, May warned that Britain could operate as an "independent trading nation" after Brexit if no trade deal is reached with the EU.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-41546701 |title=UK explores 'no deal' Brexit |date=9 October 2017 |website=BBC News |accessdate=9 December 2017}} The ''no deal'' scenario has been described by [[Nick Timothy]] as leaving the EU [with Britain] in "chaos" or not leaving the bloc at all, which he says would be a "national humiliation" on a par with the [[Suez Crisis]].{{cite news |url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/republic-of-ireland/european-commission-issues-call-for-eu-states-to-get-ready-for-nodeal-brexit-37135023.html |title=European Commission issues call for EU states to get ready for no-deal Brexit |newspaper=Belfast Telegraph}}{{cite news |url=https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/european-commission-issues-call-for-eu-states-to-get-ready-for-no-deal-brexit-856373.html |title=European Commission issues call for EU states to get ready for no-deal Brexit |date=19 July 2018|newspaper=Irish Examiner}} [[Martin Donnelly (civil servant)|Sir Martin Donnelly]] feels that no deal would be dangerous:{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-no-deal-sir-martin-donnelly-eu-theresa-may-government-economy-single-market-bad-deal-a8000186.html |title=Britain's former top civil servant just warned of the dangers of a 'no deal' Brexit |date=14 October 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} while no deal makes trade only dependent on World Trade Organisation terms which do not include services—80% of the British economy—he believes that no deal "could mean an awful lot of legal uncertainty and that's very bad for businesses, for jobs, for investment in Britain". In the [[Scottish Centre on European Relations]] paper "Brexit Uncertainty, Scotland and the UK in 2018", a conclusion is reached that the delivery of a no deal Brexit could raise support for a second independence referendum in Scotland.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-no-deal-scottish-independence-eu-expert-kirsty-hughes-a8000871.html |title=Hard Brexit could trigger new independence referendum, says Scotland's leading EU expert |date=14 October 2017 |newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} Nonetheless, according to Shadow Chancellor [[John McDonnell]] there are enough people in the House of Commons to prevent some no-agreement exit.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/no-deal-brexit-theresa-may-john-mcdonnell-labour-latest-eu-stop-commons-a8001306.html |title=Cross-party alliance 'will stop Theresa May crashing Britain out of the EU with no deal' |date=15 October 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} According to Dominic Cummings, campaign director of [[Vote Leave]], "If there's no deal, there will be significant problems that were completely avoidable".{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/vote-leave-brexit-chief-dominic-cummings-disaster-eu-european-union-theresa-may-david-davis-a8002426.html |title=The man behind Brexit says it's turning into a disaster |date=16 October 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=9 December 2017}} {| class="wikitable" |{{Graph:Chart|width=200|height=200 |xAxisTitle=Agreement |yAxisTitle=Cost in billions of euros |legend=Cost for business |type=stackedrect |x= With no deal, with deal |y1= 30, 19 |y2= 35, 16 |yAxisFormat=s |colors=#ae3C01,#2121ae,#7171fe,#c14A23,#FeFe01,#4674C0,#FeAaA5 |y1Title= UK |y2Title= EU, not including UK |yAxisMin=0 }} |- | * Source, Olivier Wayman report, ''La Tribune''{{cite news |url=https://www.latribune.fr/economie/union-europeenne/brexit-sans-accord-la-facture-serait-bien-plus-elevee-771448.html |title=Brexit : sans accord, la facture serait bien plus élevée|newspaper=[[La Tribune]] |language=fr |accessdate=3 April 2018}} pounds have been converted to euros, on 12 March 2018 |} Aviation would be particularly affected if the [[European Common Aviation Area]] and [[EU–US Open Skies Agreement]] no longer applied to the UK after a "no-deal" Brexit, since World Trade Organisation rules do not cover that sector,{{cite news |last1=Gerrard |first1=Bradley |title=With no plan B, Brexit stakes for aviation sector are sky high |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/08/18/no-plan-b-brexit-stakes-aviation-sector-sky-high/ |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=18 August 2017 |accessdate=21 September 2017}} implying that the following day a British plane could not land at an EU airport.{{cite web |url=http://www.francetvinfo.fr/monde/royaume-uni/legislatives-britanniques/brexit-le-resultat-des-legislatives-est-une-mauvaise-nouvelle-car-negocier-avec-un-partenaire-faible-nest-jamais-facile_2230587.html |title=Brexit : le résultat des législatives "est une mauvaise nouvelle" pour le président de la Fondation Robert-Schuman |date=10 June 2017 |website=FranceTVInfo.fr |language=fr |accessdate=23 June 2017}} UK government said in September 2018 that in case of no deal on aviation, UK would allow EU airlines to use British airports anyway, and expect EU countries to reciprocate.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-notices-aviation-safety/uk-would-allow-eu-airlines-to-fly-in-no-deal-brexit-would-keep-eu-safety-rules-idUSKCN1M41U8|title=UK would allow EU airlines to fly in no-deal Brexit, would keep EU safety rules|access-date=18 October 2018|date=24 September 2018|website=reuters.com}} The ''no deal scenario'' could create a disruption in transport between the United Kingdom and the European Union: for instance, with delays generated by the customs, sanitary and phytosanitary controls for road transport and ports.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/jul/19/no-deal-brexit-eu-warns-citizens-prepare-for-worst |title=Barnier welcomes Raab by stressing urgency of Irish border deadline |first1=Daniel |last1=Boffey |first2=Jennifer |last2=Rankin |date=19 July 2018|newspaper=The Guardian}} The National Police Coordination Centre has warned that no deal would result in civil disorder at the UK's ports and borders, a "real possibility" of calling upon military assistance, a rise in crime (particularly theft and robbery) and widespread illness and disease following food and drug shortages (including NHS supplies). Police officers who are EU nationals may potentially be unable to hold a warrant card (which would leave the [[Metropolitan Police]] 750 officers short), and the ability for the police to deal with criminality from non-UK residents would be undermined as the UK "falls out of the various treaties such as the [[European arrest warrant]], [[Schengen information system]] and membership of [[Europol]]".{{cite news |last1=Wheeler |first1=Caroline |title=Police plan for riots and crimewave if there is no-deal Brexit |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/police-plan-for-riots-and-crimewave-if-there-is-no-deal-brexit-frbbnjjqp |accessdate=9 September 2018 |newspaper=[[The Sunday Times]] |subscription=y |date=9 September 2018 |issn=0140-0460 |oclc=643156226}} [[Sara Thornton (police officer)|Sara Thornton]] of the [[National Police Chiefs' Council|NPCC]] said, "Existing EU tools allow us to respond quickly and intelligently to crime and terrorism in the UK and the EU – they make us better at protecting the public. The alternatives we are planning to use, where they exist, are without exception slower, more bureaucratic and ultimately less effective."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/sep/18/police-chiefs-no-deal-brexit-would-mean-loss-crime-fighting-tools|title=Police chiefs: no-deal Brexit would mean loss of crime-fighting tools|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=18 October 2018|date=18 September 2018|first1=Vikram|last1=Dodd}} Finding out if a suspect has criminal convitions will take much longer.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-45561527|title=No-deal Brexit 'could make policing harder'|publisher=BBC|access-date=18 October 2018|date=18 September 2018}} ===Contingency and preparedness{{Anchor|Yellowhammer}}=== An EU document on ''Preparedness'' outlines the plans related to various issues (with or without withdrawal agreement), and another on ''Contingency'' describes measures to answer the consequences of a ''No deal''.{{cite web |url=https://ec.europa.eu/info/sites/info/files/communication-preparing-withdrawal-brexit-preparedness.pdf |title=Preparing for the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union on 30 March 2019 |date=19 July 2018 |website=European Commission |access-date=30 August 2018}} To answer the consequences of a no deal Brexit, some players are involved in contingency planning and preparedness (but not panic). To limit the consequences of a ''no deal'' scenario, some companies, such as Airbus and Rolls-Royce, are stockpiling spares.{{cite news |url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jul/19/no-deal-brexit-britain-eu-wto-march |title=Don't worry, a no-deal Brexit won't be allowed to happen |first=Simon |last=Jenkins |date=19 July 2018 |newspaper=The Guardian}} In the Netherlands, around 1,000 customs officials are being recruited to manage the border with UK after the no deal Brexit. In the UK the need for new customs agents is estimated at 5,000. In Ireland, the need for new customs agents is estimated at 1,000. The UK is considering converting some part of the M20 motorway into a parking lot for trucks, to manage a possible 17-mile (around 25-kilometer) line of traffic, as planned by the Dover port authority. Dominic Raab's department is preparing public detailed plans to make the UK to deal with a no deal scenario for 29 March 2019. The EU Commission has published 68 notices to help various players to be aware of the Brexit consequences. The EU Commission is also considering notifying its international partners for international agreements that involved the UK as a member state, in case of no deal. The UK Treasury department is using the name "[[Operation Yellowhammer]]" for no-deal contingency planning.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/operation-yellowhammer-brexit-photo-eu-rail-access-nodeal-secret-paper-latest-document-a8525506.html |title=Operation Yellowhammer: Photo of secret government no-deal Brexit papers reveals questions over 'rail access to the EU |date=6 September 2018 |newspaper=The independent|url-access=limited}} ==The deep and special relationship scenario== The UK side has called for a deep and [[special relationship]] between UK and EU.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/brexit-latest-talks-downing-street-theresa-may-jean-claude-juncker-michel-barnier-eu-a7704561.html |title=Theresa May holds 'constructive' talks with EU leaders in London |date=27 April 2017|newspaper=The Independent |accessdate=10 February 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-johnson/uk-to-target-deep-partnership-with-eu-in-brexit-talks-johnson-idUSKBN19A0R4 |title=UK to target 'deep partnership' with EU in Brexit talks: Johnson |date=19 June 2017 |website=Reuters |accessdate=10 February 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2017/apr/07/brexit-language-divorce-special-relationship-negotiation-britain-eu |title=Don't say divorce, say special relationship: the thorny language of Brexit |first=Steven |last=Poole |date=7 April 2017|newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=10 February 2018}} ==Possibility of an extended transitional period== Most of the major UK political parties support the idea of a two-year period for applying temporary trade arrangements after the end of the membership of the EU single market, customs union and other EU agreements and before a stand-alone UK.{{cite web |url=http://www.incelaw.com/tw/knowledge-bank/the-post-brexit-transitional-period-bridge-over-troubled-negotiations |title=The post-Brexit transitional period: Bridge over troubled negotiations? |website=International Law Firm |accessdate=3 April 2018}} According to [[Michel Barnier]], the [[EU]] might have to define the conditions for a transitional period, if the [[UK]] requests one.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-3404_en.htm |title=Press release - Speech by Michel Barnier in front of the Committees of Foreign Affairs and the Committees of European Affairs of the Italian Parliament |date= |website=European Commission |accessdate=9 December 2017}} Such a transition period would begin on 30 March 2019 (European time, as Brexit occurs at midnight the day before). According to Michel Barnier, the transition period is subject to a withdrawal agreement, by law written in [[Article 50]]. ==Future trade deal between UK and EU== While negotiations between the United Kingdom and the European Union were in progress, Barnier, as the EU's chief negotiator, speaking in Rome to Committees of the Italian Parliament on 21 September 2017, stated that a future trade deal with the United Kingdom is the trade deal which will be negotiated after sufficient progress has been made on the withdrawal deal. Barnier commented that the EU will want to negotiate a future trade deal with the United Kingdom, because trade with the United Kingdom will continue.{{cite web |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-17-3404_en.htm |title=Speech by Michel Barnier in front of the Committees of Foreign Affairs and the Committees of European Affairs of the Italian Parliament, Rome |date=21 September 2017 |website=European Commission |access-date=30 August 2018}} At the same time Barnier said "the future trade deal with the United Kingdom will be particular, as it will be less about building convergence, and more about controlling future divergence. This is key to establishing fair competition." The United Kingdom's prime minister, in a speech at the [[Santa Maria Novella]] church in Florence on 22 September 2017, {{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/sep/22/mays-florence-speech-venue-represents-european-unity-not-division |title=May's Florence speech venue represents European unity, not division |date=22 September 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |access-date=30 August 2018}} proposed an economic partnership between the UK and the EU which respects both the freedoms and principles of the EU, and the wishes of the British people. At the same time she re-affirmed that after the UK leaves the EU a period of implementation would be in their mutual interest, to be agreed under Article 50 for a strictly time-limited period. The European parliament voted a Brexit resolution (the European Parliament resolution of 14 March 2018 on the framework of the future EU-UK relationship (2018/2573(RSP)) with 544 MEP against 110 (with 51 abstentions{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/unitedkingdom/en/media/news/2018/march18/association-agreement.html |title=Brexit: EP recommends association agreement for future EU-UK relations |website=European Parliament |accessdate=3 April 2018}}). The 14 page document states that an association agreement between EU and UK could be an adequate framework for the future. This resolution proposes that the agreement address four domains: trade, interior security, foreign and defense policy collaboration, and thematic cooperation (for instance for research and innovation).{{cite magazine |url=https://lentreprise.lexpress.fr/actualites/1/actualites/brexit-les-eurodeputes-proposent-un-accord-d-association-au-royaume-uni_1992319.html |title=Brexit : les eurodéputés proposent un accord d'association au Royaume-Uni |date=14 March 2018|magazine=[[L'Express]] |language=fr |accessdate=3 April 2018}}{{cite web |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=TA&reference=P8-TA-2017-0490&language=EN&ring=B8-2017-0677 |title=State of play of negotiations with the United Kingdom |date=13 December 2017 |website=European Parliament |accessdate=3 April 2018}} The resolution also urges the UK to present a clear position on all outstanding issues pertaining to its orderly withdrawal. On 13 November 2018, the UK and EU reached an agreement on the wording of the trade deal.{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/uk-european-union-thresa-may-brexit-negotiators-have-agreed-a-deal-2018-11|title=UK and EU negotiators have agreed on a Brexit deal|website=Businessinsider.com|accessdate=14 November 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46188790|title=Brexit text agreed in talks breakthrough|date=14 November 2018|accessdate=14 November 2018|website=Bbc.com}} On 14 November 2018, May's Cabinet approved the draft agreement.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/theresa-may-faces-crunch-cabinet-showdown-over-her-brexit-plans/2018/11/14/124a425a-e807-11e8-a939-9469f1166f9d_story.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=14 November 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181114174051/https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/theresa-may-faces-crunch-cabinet-showdown-over-her-brexit-plans/2018/11/14/124a425a-e807-11e8-a939-9469f1166f9d_story.html# |archive-date=14 November 2018 |dead-url=yes }} Shortly after it was approved by the British Cabinet, the European Commission published the 585 pages draft withdrawal agreement.[https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/draft_withdrawal_agreement_0.pdf] == See also == {{Wikipedia books |1=Brexit |3=Brexit, Article 50, and other articles }} {{Wikipedia books|Britain, Ireland and the European Union}} * The [[European Atomic Energy Community]] (Euratom) – legally distinct from the EU but having the same membership, from which the United Kingdom is also withdrawing * {{Books-inline|Brexit, Article 50, and other articles}} (includes articles on UK and EU treaties, policies, institutions, law and justice, and EU history) ==References== [[File:DufayBinchois.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Composer [[Guillaume Dufay]] (left) and [[Gilles Binchois]] (right), [[Martin le Franc]], "Champion des Dames"]]
The '''Burgundian School''' was a group of composers active in the 15th century in what is now northern and eastern [[France]], [[Belgium]], and the [[Netherlands]], centered on the court of the [[Duchy of Burgundy|Dukes of Burgundy]].
The main names associated with this school are [[Guillaume Dufay]], [[Gilles Binchois]], [[Antoine Busnois]] and (as an influence), the English composer [[John Dunstaple]]. The Burgundian School was the first phase of activity of the [[Franco-Flemish School]], the central musical practice of the [[Renaissance music|Renaissance]] in Europe.
==Background==
In late [[Medieval]] and early [[Renaissance]] Europe, cultural centers tended to move from one place to another due to changing political stability and the presence of either the spiritual or temporal power, for instance the [[Pope]], [[Anti-pope]] or the [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. In the 14th century, the main centers of musical activity were northern [[France]], [[Avignon]], and [[Italy]], as represented by [[Guillaume de Machaut]] and the ''[[ars nova]]'', the ''[[ars subtilior]]'', and [[Francesco Landini|Landini]] respectively; Avignon had a brief but important cultural flowering because it was the location of the Papacy during the [[Western Schism]]. When France was ravaged by the [[Hundred Years' War]] (1337–1453), the cultural center migrated farther east, to towns in Burgundy and the [[Low Countries]], known then collectively as the [[Netherlands]].<ref name="Wright, Grove">Wright, Grove</ref>
During the reign of the [[House of Valois]], Burgundy was the most powerful and stable political division in western Europe, and added, a bit at a time, [[Flanders]], [[Brabant (province)|Brabant]], [[Holland]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Alsace]] and [[Lorraine (province)|Lorraine]]. Especially during the reigns of [[Philip the Good]] (1419 – 1467) and [[Charles the Bold]] (1467 – 1477), this entire area, loosely known as Burgundy, was a center of musical creativity. Most of the musical activity did not take place in what is modern-day Burgundy, which has its capital in [[Dijon]] (even though the Dukes of Burgundy maintained an administrative center there). The main centers of music-making were [[Brussels]], [[Bruges]], [[Lille]], and [[Arras]], as well as smaller towns in that same general area.<ref name="Wright, Grove"/>
Musicians from the region came to Burgundy to study and further their own careers as the reputation of the area spread. The Burgundian rulers were not merely patrons of the arts, but took an active part: Charles the Bold himself played the [[harp]], and composed [[chanson]]s and [[motet]]s (although none have survived with reliable attribution). The worldly dukes also encouraged the composition of secular music to a degree seen only rarely before in European music history, a characteristic which itself defines the Burgundian epoch as a Renaissance phenomenon.<ref>Reese, p. 4-8</ref>
This migration of musical culture east from Paris to Burgundy also corresponds with the conventional (and by no means universally accepted) division of music history into [[Medieval music|Medieval]] and [[Renaissance music|Renaissance]]; while [[Guillaume de Machaut]] is often considered to be one of the last Medieval composers, Dufay is often considered to be the first significant Renaissance composer.
Charles the Bold was killed in 1477 in the [[Battle of Nancy]], during one of his attempts to add territory to his empire. After his death, music continued to flourish as before, but the region was split politically, with the duchy of Burgundy being absorbed into France, and most of the Low Countries becoming part of the holdings of the [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Habsburgs]]. Both the French court and the Habsburgs were patrons of music; however a French style began to diverge from that of the Low Countries, especially in secular music, and in the period after 1500.
==Composers==
The history of Burgundian music began with the organization of the chapel in 1384; twenty years later, it rivaled the famous establishment at Avignon in splendor. Names associated with this early phase of Burgundian music include [[Johannes Tapissier]] and [[Nicolas Grenon]], who carried the tradition across to the next phase of the chapel, when it was reorganized in 1415. Other early composers there were [[Hugo de Lantins|Hugo]] and [[Arnold de Lantins]], both of whom Dufay later met in Italy.
Of all the names associated with the Burgundian School, the most famous was [[Guillaume Dufay]], who was probably the most famous composer in Europe in the 15th century. He wrote music in many of the forms which were current, music which was melodic, singable and memorable (more than half of his sacred music consists of simple harmonizations of [[plainsong]], for example). Contemporary with Dufay were composers such as [[Gilles Binchois]], who was at the Burgundian court between approximately 1430 and 1460, and [[Hayne van Ghizeghem]], a composer, singer and soldier who may have been killed in the last military campaign of Charles the Bold.
After the death of Dufay in 1474, the most prominent Burgundian musician was [[Antoine Busnois]], who was also a prolific composer of chansons, and who possibly wrote the famous [[L'homme armé]] tune.
==Musical style and forms== [[File:Burgundian cadence on D.png|thumb|[[Burgundian cadence]] on D; note the parallel fourths between upper voices.<ref>White, John D. (1976). ''The Analysis of Music'', p.129-130. {{ISBN|0-13-033233-X}}.</ref> {{audio|Burgundian cadence on D.mid|Play}}]]
Burgundian composers favored secular forms, at least while they worked in Burgundian lands; much sacred music survives, especially from those composers who spent time in Italy, for example in the papal choir. The most prominent secular forms used by the Burgundians were the four ''[[formes fixes]]'' ([[Rondeau (forme fixe)|rondeau]], [[ballade (forme fixe)|ballade]], [[virelai]], and [[bergerette]]), all generically known as [[chanson]]s. Of the four, the rondeau was by far the most popular; at any rate more rondeaux have survived than any other form. Most of the rondeaux were in three voices, and in French, though there are a few in other languages. In most of the rondeaux, the uppermost voice (the "superius") was texted, and the other voices were most likely played by instruments. The bergerette was developed by the Burgundians themselves; it was like a virelai, but shorter, having only one stanza.
Most of the composers also wrote sacred music in Latin; this was to remain true for the next several generations. They wrote both [[mass]]es and [[motet]]s, as well as cycles of [[Magnificat]]s. During the period, the mass transformed from a group of individual sections written by different composers, often using a [[head-motif]] technique, to unified cycles based on a [[cantus firmus]]. Dufay, Binchois, Busnois, [[Reginald Liebert]] and others all wrote cyclic masses. One of the favorite tunes used as a cantus firmus was the renowned [[l'homme armé]], which was set not only by the Burgundians but by composers of subsequent centuries; indeed it was commonest tune used as a basis for mass composition in all of music history, with more than forty surviving masses featuring the melody. David Fallows writes of it in the [[New Grove]]: "It is hard to think of any other melody in the history of music that has yielded so much music of the highest quality."<ref>David Fallows. "L'homme armé." In Grove Music Online. Oxford Music Online, http://www.oxfordmusiconline.com/subscriber/article/grove/music/16553 (accessed July 22, 2010).</ref>
During the period the motet transformed from the [[isorhythm]]ic model of the 14th century to the smoothly [[polyphony|polyphonic]], sectional composition seen in the work of the later Burgundians such as Busnois. In the motets, as well as the masses and other sacred music, a common musical technique employed was [[fauxbourdon]], a harmonization of an existing chant in parallel 6-3 chords, occasionally ornamented to prevent monotony. Composition using fauxbourdon allowed sung text to be clearly understood, but yet avoided the plainness of simple chant. Burgundian motets tended to be in Latin, written for three voices with the top voice being the most important. An example of a Burgundian motet is ''Quam pulchra es'', written by Dunstaple in the early 15th century.
Instrumental music was also cultivated at the Burgundian courts, often for dancing. A peculiarity of the Burgundian instrumental style is that the dukes preferred music for loud instruments ([[trumpet]]s, [[tambourin]]s, [[shawm]]s, [[bagpipe]]s) and more of this survives than for other current instruments such as the lute or the harp. In contemporary practice, the loud instruments would usually play from an elevated location, such as a balcony, while the other instruments would play closer to the dancers.<ref name="Wright, Grove"/>
Instrumental forms included the ''[[basse danse]]'', or ''bassadanza'', which was a ceremonial dance of a rather dignified character, and relatively slow tempo. Typically it was in a duple meter subdivided into threes (in modern notation, 6/8), and often the dance would be immediately followed by a quick dance, the ''[[tordion]]'' or ''pas de Brabant''.<ref>Gleason, p. 101-102.</ref>
The Burgundian School was the first generation of what is sometimes known as the [[Dutch School (music)|Netherlands School]], several generations of composers spanning 150 years who composed in the [[polyphony|polyphonic]] style associated with the mainstream of Renaissance practice. Later generations, which were no longer specifically associated with either the court or the region Burgundy but were interlinked by adjacent geography and by common musical practice, included such names as [[Johannes Ockeghem]], [[Jacob Obrecht]], [[Josquin des Prez]], [[Adrian Willaert]] and [[Orlandus Lassus]].
==Manuscript sources==
There are approximately 65 manuscript sources which contain music by Burgundian composers. The most prominent of these include:
* [[Canonici Manuscript]] (containing music from around 1400 to 1440). This manuscript is at the [[Bodleian Library]] in [[Oxford, England]]; it is named after a previous owner, Matteo Luigi Canonici, an 18th-century Venetian Jesuit. It has 380 compositions in all, including works by 60 composers. Both sacred and secular music are well represented in this collection. * [[Laborde Chansonnier]] (containing music mainly composed during the reign of Charles the Bold, 1467–1477). It is named after the Marquis de Laborde, and is presently at the [[Library of Congress]] in Washington, DC. It has 106 pieces of music in all. * [[Mellon Chansonnier]] (containing music from approximately 1440 to 1477). It is named after [[Paul Mellon]], who gave it to [[Yale University]]; currently it is in the Beinecke Library there. It has 57 compositions, and includes some non-Burgundian music as well (for example, works by contemporary English and Italian composers) * [[Dijon Chansonnier]] (containing music from approximately 1470 to 1475). Some of the music is by composers not normally associated with the Burgundian school, such as Ockeghem, [[Loyset Compère]], and [[Johannes Tinctoris]]. It is at the public library in Dijon, and contains 161 pieces of music in all. * [[El Escorial Chansonnier]] (containing music from about 1430 to 1445). It is in the Biblioteca del Monasterio, [[El Escorial]], V.III.24, and is commonly referred to as EscA. It contains a total of 62 compositions, only one of which is attributed (to [[Gilles Binchois]]), although many of the rest have been assigned to Binchois, Dunstaple, Dufay, and others, on stylistic grounds.<ref>Gleason, 95-96</ref>
==Burgundian composers== {{unreferenced section|date=November 2012}} {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *[[Johannes Tapissier]] (c.1370–c.1410) *[[Guillaume Dufay]] (?1397–1474) *[[Jean Cousin (composer)|Jean Cousin]] (b. before 1425, d. after 1475) *[[Hugo de Lantins]] (fl. c.1430) *[[Arnold de Lantins]] (fl. c.1430) *[[Johannes Legrant]] fl. c. 1420-1440 *[[Guillaume Legrant]] fl. 1405-1449 *[[Reginaldus Libert]] (fl. c.1425–1435) *[[Gilles Binchois]] (c.1400–1460) *[[Johannes Brassart]] (c.1400–1455) *[[Hayne van Ghizeghem]] (c.1445–c.1480) *[[Pierre Fontaine (composer)|Pierre Fontaine]] (c.1380 - c.1450) *[[Nicolas Grenon]] (c. 1375–1456) *[[Gilles Joye]] (1424/1425–1483) *[[Robert Morton (composer)|Robert Morton]] (c.1430–c.1479) *[[Antoine Busnois]] (c.1430–1492) *[[Guillaume le Rouge]] ([[floruit|fl.]] 1450–1465) *[[Adrien Basin]] (fl. 1457–1476) *[[Jacobus Vide]] (fl. 1405–1433) {{colend}}
==References==
* Craig Wright, "Burgundy", in ''The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians'', ed. Stanley Sadie. 20 vol. London, Macmillan Publishers Ltd., 1980. {{ISBN|1-56159-174-2}} * [[Gustave Reese]], ''Music in the Renaissance''. New York, W.W. Norton & Co., 1954. {{ISBN|0-393-09530-4}} * Harold Gleason and Warren Becker, ''Music in the Middle Ages and Renaissance'' (Music Literature Outlines Series I). Bloomington, Indiana. Frangipani Press, 1986. {{ISBN|0-89917-034-X}} * Walter H. Kemp, ''Burgundian Court Song in the Time of Binchois: The Anonymous Chansons of El Escorial, MS V.III.24''. Oxford, Clarendon Press. 1990.

[[Department of Health (Philippines)|Department of Health]] | outcome = | casualties1 = 3,281 hospitalized after receiving Dengvaxia (1,967 with dengue indication){{cite news|title=DOH: Over 3,000 students hospitalized after Dengvaxia shot|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/200187-doh-students-hospitalized-dengvaxia|work=[[Rappler]]}} | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = 62 children ({{as of|2018|4|07|lc=y|df=US}}){{NoteTag|Four with dengue indication.{{cite news|title=PAO sees 'pattern' in deaths of 4 Dengvaxia recipients|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/01/10/18/pao-sees-pattern-in-deaths-of-4-dengvaxia-recipients|work=ABS-CBN News}}}}{{cite news|title=DOH says 62 kids may have died after receiving Dengvaxia|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/980755/doh-says-62-kids-may-have-died-after-receiving-dengvaxia|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = | charges = | trial = | verdict = | convictions = | sentence = | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = | blank1_label = | blank2_label = | website = | notes = }} The Philippine [[Department of Health (Philippines)|Department of Health]] (DOH), on late November 2017, temporarily suspended a school-based [[Dengue vaccine|dengue vaccination]] (also known as "Dengvaxia", {{IPA-tl|dɛŋˈvakʃa}}) program after French drug based vaccine maker [[Sanofi Pasteur]] made a statement that its product poses higher risks to people without prior [[dengue fever|dengue]] infection.[https://www.rappler.com/nation/190056-doh-stops-dengue-vaccination-program-dengvaxia-sanofi "DOH suspends dengue vaccination program"]. ''Rappler''.[https://technology.inquirer.net/69907/pharma-firm-issues-caution-anti-dengue-vaccine-sanofi-dengvaxia-vaccine-health-dengue "Pharma firm issues caution on use of anti-dengue vaccine"]. As a result, the '''Dengvaxia controversy''', or '''Dengvaxia mess''',{{cite news|title=DOJ compels VACC, Vanguard to submit evidence on Dengvaxia complaint|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/03/23/18/doj-compels-vacc-vanguard-to-submit-evidence-on-dengvaxia-complaint|work=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]]}} began to emerge following the reports of several children dying from various complications allegedly attributed to the dengue vaccine. ==Background== In April 2016, the Department of Health (DOH), launched the dengue vaccination campaign in [[Regions of the Philippines|regions]] [[Central Luzon]], [[Calabarzon]] and [[Metro Manila]], where about 700,000 individuals received at least one dose of the vaccine.{{cite news|title=DOH suspends dengue immunization program over potential health risk|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/01/1764262/doh-suspends-dengue-immunization-program-over-potential-health-risk|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} The government paid P3.5-billion for the vaccine.{{cite news|title=Senate invites Aquino to vaccine probe|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/13/1767890/senate-invites-aquino-vaccine-probe}} On December 1, 2015, former [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Benigno Aquino III]] met with executives of Sanofi Pasteur in a courtesy call in [[Paris]], making the Philippines the first Asian country to approve the commercial sale of Dengvaxia. ==Events== Following the attempt by the dengue vaccination maker Sanofi Pasteur on November 29, 2017,{{cite news|title=Sanofi updates information on dengue vaccine|url=http://mediaroom.sanofi.com/sanofi-updates-information-on-dengue-vaccine/|work=Sanofi Pasteur|date=November 29, 2017}} the Philippine Department of Health (DOH) suspended the vaccination program based in schools owing to the concern that it worsens the disease in some cases where the recipient had no previous exposure.{{cite news|title=Suspended dengue vaccine was given to 730,000 children, Philippines says|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/05/suspended-dengue-vaccine-children-philippines-sanofi|work=[[The Guardian]]}} DOH Secretary Francisco Duque III said "In the light of this new analysis, the DOH will place the dengue vaccination on hold while review and consultation is ongoing with experts, key stakeholders and the World Health Organization." On December 2, 2017, the government of [[Makati]] immediately suspended its anti-dengue vaccination drive following its statement.{{cite news|title=Makati suspends anti-dengue vaccination program|url=http://www.canadianinquirer.net/2017/12/02/makati-suspends-anti-dengue-vaccination-program/|work=Philippine Canadian Inquirer}} In its statement, pharmaceutical company [[Sanofi Pasteur]] reported concerns that [[Filipinos]], mostly schoolchildren, could be potentially be at risk of a more severe disease, where the recipient of the vaccine had not had a previous [[Dengue fever|dengue]] infection. On December 4, 2017, Sanofi denied that they made Filipinos into “[[Guinea pig|guinea pigs]]”, explaining that the vaccine program was conducted by the DOH, not Sanofi.{{cite news| title=Sanofi, DOH allay dengue vaccine fears |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/04/1765198/sanofi-doh-allay-dengue-vaccine-fears |work=[[The Philippine Star]]}}{{cite news |title=Sanofi denies Pinoys became ‘guinea pigs,’ says no reported Dengvaxia deaths in PH |url=http://www.interaksyon.com/sanofi-denies-filipinos-became-dengvaxia-guinea-pigs-explains-severe-dengue-allays-fears/ |work=[[News5]]}} Dr Ruby Dizon, a medical director of Sanofi, said that the dengue vaccination would not cause "severe dengue".{{cite news|title=Ex-DOH chief ready to face probe over Dengvaxia mess|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/12/05/17/ex-doh-chief-ready-to-face-probe-over-dengvaxia-mess|work=ABS-CBN News}} [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator]] [[JV Ejercito]], chair of the Senate Committee on Health and Demography, is seeking to identify by January 2018 whether there was an irregularity in the procurement of the vaccine.{{cite news|title=Senate to probe dengue vaccine in January|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/02/1764274/senate-probe-dengue-vaccine-january|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} Senator [[Risa Hontiveros]] urged the government to address the health threats posed by the vaccine.{{cite news|title=Risa says Sanofi must pay over Dengvaxia mess; DOJ orders probe of PNoy gov’t’s P3.5-B vaccination drive|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/risa-urges-govt-to-create-database-of-children-given-dengvaxia-says-sanofi-must-shoulder-needs-of-affected-pinoys/|work=[[News5]]}} The [[Food and Drug Administration (Philippines)|Food and Drug Administration of the Philippines]] ordered Sanofi to stop distributing of Dengvaxia into the country.{{cite news|title=PH gov’t orders Sanofi to stop sale, distribution of Dengvaxia|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/ph-govt-orders-sanofi-to-stop-sale-distribution-of-dengvaxia/|work=[[News5]]}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20171205044730/http://www.fda.gov.ph/advisories-2/476894-fda-advisory-no-2017-318-suspension-of-sale-marketing-distribution-of-sanofi-pasteur-inc-s-tetravalent-vaccine-live-attenuated-dengvaxia "FDA Advisory No. 2017-318 || Suspension of Sale/Marketing/Distribution of Sanofi Pasteur, Inc.’s Tetravalent Vaccine (Live, Attenuated)(Dengvaxia)"]. Archived from the [http://www.fda.gov.ph/advisories-2/476894-fda-advisory-no-2017-318-suspension-of-sale-marketing-distribution-of-sanofi-pasteur-inc-s-tetravalent-vaccine-live-attenuated-dengvaxia original]. [[Food and Drug Administration (Philippines)|Food and Drug Administration]]. Former Health Secretary [[Janette Garin]] said she welcomed the investigation which will be conducted by the [[Department of Justice (Philippines)|Philippine Department of Justice]].{{cite news|title=WATCH {{!}} Garin ready to face govt’s Dengvaxia probe|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/garin-says-shes-ready-to-face-govts-dengvaxia-probe/|work=[[News5]]}} Presidential spokesperson Harry Roque told the media that 10 percent of the 733,000 schoolchildren{{NoteTag|Some sources say 700,000{{cite news|title=LIVE: Senate hearing on Dengvaxia|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/190965-senate-hearing-dengvaxia-dengue-vaccine|work=[[Rappler]]}} or 830,000{{cite news|title=DOJ wants right expert to look into alleged Dengvaxia deaths|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/02/08/18/doj-wants-right-expert-to-look-into-alleged-dengvaxia-deaths|work=ABS-CBN News}}}} were at risk of dengue infection.{{cite news|title=Filipinos not made guinea pigs – Sanofi|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/949830/filipinos-not-made-guinea-pigs-sanofi|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Since then, the [[Department of Education (Philippines)|Philippine Department of Education]] has closely monitored the students who have been injected by the vaccine.{{cite news |title=DepEd monitors students administered with Dengvaxia |url=https://news.mb.com.ph/2017/12/12/deped-monitors-students-administered-with-dengvaxia/ |work=[[Manila Bulletin]]}} Hontiveros said that Sanofi should take liability for the medical expenses of those who contracted severe dengue fever after receiving doses of the vaccine.{{cite news|title=Hontiveros: Sanofi should take on medical expenses of those who were vaccinated|url=https://news.mb.com.ph/2017/12/16/hontiveros-sanofi-should-take-on-medical-expenses-of-those-who-were-vaccinated/|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]}} Sanofi representative Thomas Triomphe "was forced to apologize" during the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines|House of Representatives]] hearing on the Dengvaxia dengue vaccine.{{cite news |title=Sanofi exec forced to apologize during Dengvaxia inquiry |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/952099/sanofi-exec-forced-to-apologize-at-dengvaxia-inquiry |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Former [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Benigno Aquino III]], who approved the vaccination program in 2016, expressed interest on attending the Senate hearing.{{cite news|title=Aquino ready to face Dengvaxia probe at Senate|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/13/1768001/aquino-ready-face-dengvaxia-probe-senate}} On December 16, Aquino told reporters that "With the announcement of Sanofi and the reactions to it, there has been a lot of tension building up and I think it is incumbent upon me even as a citizen to try and allay certain fears, to put it in the proper perspective, to put it on the proper level".{{cite news|title=Aquino: It’s my duty to explain|url=https://m.inquirer.net/newsinfo/952868|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer ]]}} Secretary Duque reminded the public, especially parents, that "the vaccine is not a 'standalone' preventive measure against dengue."{{cite news |title=Duque to public: Don’t rely too much on vaccination to fight dengue |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/636765/duque-to-public-don-rsquo-t-rely-too-much-on-vaccination-to-fight-dengue/story/ |work=GMA News}} On December 15, 2017, former Education and Skills Development chief Augusto Syjuco Jr filed "mass murder and plunder" complaints against Aquino and former health secretary Janette Garin over the controversial vaccination program.{{cite news |title=Aquino, Garin face mass murder, plunder raps over dengvaxia controversy |url=http://www.canadianinquirer.net/2017/12/15/aquino-garin-face-mass-murder-plunder-raps-over-dengvaxia-controversy/ |work=Philippine Canadian Inquirer |date=December 15, 2017}} Former health secretary Enrique Ona blamed his successor Janette Garin, who advised former president Benigno Aquino lll to purchase the Dengvaxia.{{cite news|title=Dengue vaccine fiasco: Enrique Ona blames Janette Garin |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2017/12/19/1769792/dengue-vaccine-fiasco-enrique-ona-blames-janette-garin}} On February 2, 2018, the University of the Philippines-Philippine General Hospital (UP-PGH) issued a report stating that three out of 14 children who died after receiving Dengvaxia had an indication of dengue despite immunization.{{cite news|title=3 out of 14 kids died of dengue after Dengvaxia shot – UP-PGH panel|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/195070-children-dead-dengue-dengvaxia-up-pgh-panel|work=[[Rappler]]}} On February 3, a group of doctors, including former health secretary Esperanza Cabral, urged the Public Attorney's Office (PAO) to stop conducting autopsies.{{cite news |title='Stop PAO autopsies on suspected Dengvaxia victims' |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/195176-esperanza-cabral-doctors-doj-stop-pao-autopsies-dengvaxia-victims |work=[[Rappler]]}} On February 21, Senator [[Richard J. Gordon|Richard Gordon]] said that the DOH must be liable for the controversy.{{cite news |url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/196561-gordon-says-doh-liable-over-dengvaxia-mess |title=Gordon says DOH 'liable' over Dengvaxia mess |work=[[Rappler]]}} On March 13, Senator Gordon formally terminated the investigation of the controversy.{{cite news|title=Gordon vows ‘hard-hitting’ report as Senate ends Dengvaxia probe|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/198046-gordon-vows-hard-hitting-report-senate-ends-dengvaxia-probe|work=[[Rappler]]}} On February 26, Aquino appeared for the first time at House inquiry about the controversy; he said that the controversy has been "politicized",{{cite news|title=Aquino hits ‘loud’ forensic expert on Dengvaxia mess|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/971363/aquino-hits-loud-forensic-expert-on-dengvaxia-mess|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} but the [[Malacañang Palace]] distanced itself from Aquino's allegations.{{cite news|title=Dengvaxia mess ‘politicized’? Certainly not because of Duterte, says Palace|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/971395/dengvaxia-dengue-vaccine-aquino-palace-duterte-politicized-probe|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} On February 27, the opposition Representatives such as Gary Alejano of Magdalo and [[Edcel Lagman]] of Albay urged [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Rodrigo Duterte]] to intervene about the dispute between the PAO and DOH.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1UHjLAXQggk "Bandila: Ilang mambabatas, hinamon si Duterte ukol sa Dengvaxia"]. On March 3, about 200 families of Dengvaxia vacinees joined the advocacy run held in Quezon Memorial Circle.{{cite news|title=Mga pamilya ng naturukan ng Dengvaxia, nagsagawa ng 'advocacy run'|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/03/03/18/mga-pamilya-ng-naturukan-ng-dengvaxia-nagsagawa-ng-advocacy-run|work=ABS-CBN News}} Sanofi stated that they will make a decision on seeking regulatory approval for dengue vaccine Dengvaxia in the United States, despite the health scare in the country, after they have had a meeting with the [[US Food and Drug Administration]].{{cite news|title=Sanofi may seek U.S. approval for Dengvaxia despite Philippines outrage|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sanofi-dengue-interview/sanofi-may-seek-u-s-approval-for-dengvaxia-despite-philippines-outrage-idUSKCN1GJ2EL|work=[[Reuters]]}} === Charges === On April 5, Public Attorney’s Office filed the criminal charges (reckless imprudence resulting in homicide under Article 365 of the Revised Penal Code and violation of Republic Act No. 9745 (Anti-Torture Act) and torture) against the Former Health Secretary Janette Garin and other former officials.{{cite news|title=Garin, other Health execs charged over ‘Dengvaxia deaths’|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/garin-other-health-execs-charged-over-dengvaxia-deaths/390637/|work=[[The Manila Times]]}}{{cite news|title=Garin: Raps filed by parents of alleged Dengvaxia victims ‘have no scientific basis’|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/980437/garin-dengvaxia-dengue-vaccine-complaint-parents-alleged-deaths-victims|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} However, Garin said that the charges have no basis and vowed to file a counter-charge against PAO.{{cite news|title=Raps filed vs. Garin, 34 others over alleged Dengvaxia deaths|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/news/nation/648968/raps-filed-vs-garin-34-others-over-dengvaxia-deaths/story/|work=GMA News}} The families of four children — Aejay Bautista (11), Lenard Baldonado (10), Zandro Colite (11), and Angelica Pestilos (10), whose deaths had been linked to Dengvaxia — also filed the charges.{{cite news|title=Dengvaxia victims' kin file complaint vs DOH, Sanofi, Zuellig execs|url=https://www.rappler.com/nation/199657-dengvaxia-victims-families-criminal-complaint-doh-sanofi-zuellig|work=[[Rappler]]}} On April 19, PAO filed criminal complaints before the [[Department of Justice (Philippines)|Department of Justice]] (DOJ), including the incumbent Health Secretary Francisco Duque III, following the death of the 13-year-old girl after receiving Dengvaxia on November 17, 2017.{{cite news|title=Duque, other DOH officials face criminal raps over Dengvaxia mess|url=https://news.abs-cbn.com/news/04/19/18/duque-other-doh-officials-face-criminal-raps-over-dengvaxia-mess|work=ABS-CBN News}} Duque fires back by describing the charges against him as "malicious and [[Oppression|oppressive]]" and he also said that he has nothing to do with the implementation of the dengue immunization program since he was seated as the secretary last October 2017.{{cite news|title=Duque blasts PAO chief for 'malicious' Dengvaxia rap|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/04/20/18/duque-blasts-pao-chief-for-malicious-dengvaxia-rap|work=ABS-CBN News}} === Gordon's draft report === On April 11, Gordon released his draft report, stating that Aquino is guilty of "malfeasance, misfeasance and nonfeasance" in connection to that controversy.{{cite news|title=Senate blue ribbon on Dengvaxia mess: Aquino simply did not care|url=https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/04/11/1804941/senate-blue-ribbon-dengvaxia-mess-aquino-simply-did-not-care|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} The blue ribbon committee also told Aquino for "simply not caring" because the lives of Filipino children in grave danger. Gordon said that Aquino, former Budget Secretary Florencio Abad, Garin and other conspirators must be prosecuted for the Dengvaxia mess.{{cite news|title=Aquino, Abad, Garin ‘caused’ Dengvaxia ‘tragedy’ – draft report|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/981645/news-senate-blue-ribbon-committee-dengvaxia-benigno-aquino-iii-florencio-abad-janette-garin-sanofi|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Gordon slammed Aquino by saying that "he's insensitive and lacks compassion."''"Former President Aquino is responsible because he caused the purchase of Dengvaxia and in the process caused irreversible damage, possibly death, to children, [and] anxiety, sleepless nights, unnecessary expense on the part of the parents and guardians. The greatest sin and transgression of Aquino was to put the lives of Filipino children in grave peril. He simply did not care. Manhid siya at walang malasakit (He's insensitive and lacks compassion).""'' ([https://www.rappler.com/nation/199996-richard-gordon-dengvaxia-draft-committee-report "Gordon report: File criminal charges vs Aquino, Garin, Abad over Dengvaxia mess"]) — [[Rappler]] However, left-wing figures called Gordon’s report “one-sided,” and Senator [[Antonio Trillanes|Antonio Trillanes IV]] defends Aquino by saying that Gordon's report was "black propaganda".{{cite news|title=Gordon draft report 'black propaganda', won't pass Senate scrutiny - Trillanes|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/news/04/12/18/gordon-draft-report-black-propaganda-wont-pass-senate-scrutiny-trillanes|work=ABS-CBN News}} Aquino reacted by saying, “What should we expect from the Dick Gordon show?”.{{cite news|title=Clearly it’s ‘Dick Gordon show,’ says Aquino on Dengvaxia draft report|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/981734/its-dick-gordon-show-says-aquino-on-dengvaxia-draft-report|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Also, Senator Ejercito said that while Aquino is "guilty of negligence", Garin and Abad are the ones who should be held liable.{{cite news|title=Senators cool to Gordon report on Dengvaxia|url=https://www.philstar.com/headlines/2018/04/13/1805447/senators-cool-gordon-report-dengvaxia|work=[[The Philippine Star]]}} On April 15, Gordon said he expected at least 10 senators to sign his report holding former President Benigno Aquino III and other officials liable.{{cite news|title=Gordon: 10 senators to sign committee report on Dengvaxia probe|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/982569/gordon-10-senators-to-sign-committee-report-on-dengvaxia-probe|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} Senator [[Panfilo Lacson]] will not sign the report due to "unreasonable comments" about him.{{cite web|title=Lacson won’t sign Dengvaxia report due to Gordon’s ‘unreasonable’ remark|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/982739/lacson-gordon-dengvaxia-draft-committee-report-dengue-vaccine-senate|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} On April 17, Aside from Gordon, who already signed the report, Senators [[Ralph Recto]], [[Manny Pacquiao]], [[Sherwin Gatchalian]], [[Tito Sotto]], [[Gregorio Honasan]], [[Juan Miguel Zubiri]], [[JV Ejercito]], [[Nancy Binay]], and [[Grace Poe]] have signed.{{cite news|title=9 senators have signed report seeking charges vs former President Aquino|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/983106/dengvaxia-benigno-aquino-richard-gordon-draft-report|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} On April 20, Senator [[Sonny Angara]] also signed.{{cite news|title=Angara signs blue ribbon Dengvaxia report with ‘reservations’, too|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/983931/angara-signs-blue-ribbon-dengvaxia-report-with-reservations-too|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]}} ==Casualties== Since the announcement by Sanofi, at least 65 children have died {{as of|2018|7|pre=early|lc=y}}, allegedly after receiving a vaccination. The victims' parents blamed the dengue vaccine for the deaths of their children.[https://web.archive.org/web/20171220063636/http://www.philstar.com/bansa/2017/12/20/1770056/anak-namin-namatay-sa-dengvaxia "Anak namin namatay sa Dengvaxia"] (in Tagalog). Archived from the [http://www.philstar.com/bansa/2017/12/20/1770056/anak-namin-namatay-sa-dengvaxia original]. ''Pilipino Star Ngayon''. Retrieved December 20, 2017. Most of the deaths are caused by internal bleedings in heart, lungs, and brain based on the autopsy conducted by PAO.{{cite news|title=Bakit namamaga ang internal organs ng mga namatay umano sa Dengvaxia?|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/focus/01/11/18/bakit-namamaga-ang-internal-organs-ng-mga-namatay-umano-sa-dengvaxia|work=ABS-CBN News|language=Tagalog}}[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70WD_Y88kOI "TV Patrol: Bangkay ng binatilyong 3 beses tinurukan ng Dengvaxia, sinuri"] ''ABS-CBN News'' – via YouTube.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IlVxcR2cWrw "TV Patrol: Nasuri ng PAO na naturukan umano ng Dengvaxia, umabot na sa 41"]. ''ABS-CBN News'' – via YouTube. Duque angrily confronted the summoned hospital officials after he learned that four hospitals in Cavite allegedly refused to admit the Dengvaxia vaccinees because "there is no room for the patient".[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0kBMPUCZaw "TV Patrol: Duque, sinugod ang mga ospital na 'tumanggi' sa naturukan ng Dengvaxia"] ''ABS-CBN News'' – via YouTube.
(1:41-1:47) ''...Hindi naman pala puno ang hospital pero wala lang daw bakanteng kwarto noon para sa kaso ng bata.'' ==Reactions== Netizens, as well as Senator Ejercito, expressed frustration on February 5, blaming the PAO for panic in dengue vaccination.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ebxzx1UgH2k "Bandila: PAO, binabatikos dahil sa 'panic' sa Dengvaxia"] (in Tagalog). [[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN News]] — via [[YouTube]]. Attorney Persida Acosta of the PAO said that the PAO should not be blamed for that panic but Sanofi Pasteur itself. ==Notes== {{NoteFoot}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20180209041938/http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/12/09/The-Dengvaxia-controversy.html TIMELINE: The Dengvaxia controversy (Archived)] [[Category:2017 in the Philippines]] [[Category:2018 in the Philippines]] [[Category:2017 controversies]] [[Category:2018 controversies]] [[Category:Health disasters in the Philippines]] [[Category:2018 health disasters]]

{{primary sources|date=September 2011}} The '''Design Automation Conference''', or '''DAC''', is an annual event, a combination of a technical conference and a trade show, both specializing in [[electronic design automation]] (EDA).
DAC is the oldest and largest conference in EDA, started in 1964. It grew out of the SHARE ("Society to Help Avoid Redundant Effort") design automation workshop. Its originators Marie Pistilli and Pasquale (Pat) Pistilli were honored by the EDA community. Pat received the highest honor in EDA industry, the [[Phil Kaufman Award]], for this effort<ref>[http://dsp-fpga.com/articles/looking-back-at-the-milestones-as-dac-50-approaches/ "Looking back at the milestones as DAC-50 approaches"], Mike Demler, March 19, 2013 (retrieved April 4, 2013)</ref> and Marie was honored by having an award established in her name, Marie R. Pistilli Women in EDA Achievement Award,<ref>[https://dac.com/content/women-electronic-design "Women in Electronic Design"]</ref> known as the Marie R. Pistilli Women in Engineering Achievement Award since 2016.<ref>[https://dac.com/sites/default/files/files/2016/53dac_wwed_nomination.pdf "2016 Marie R. Pistilli Women in Engineering Achievement Award Nominations"] (retrieved February 29, 2016)</ref>
Up until the mid-'70s, DAC had sessions on all types of design automation, including mechanical and architectural. After that, for all intents and purposes, only topics concerned with electronic design have been included. Also until the mid-'70s, DAC was strictly a technical conference. Then a few companies started to request space to show their products, and within a few years the trade show portion of DAC became the main focus of the event. The first commercial DAC was held in June 1984. As a rough metric of the importance of the trade show portion, about 5,500 people attended DAC in 2005, whereas ICCAD, at least as strong technically but with no trade show, drew perhaps a tenth as many attendees.
Other similar conferences are the [[International Conference on Computer-Aided Design]], or ICCAD (technical only, no trade show), [[Design Automation and Test in Europe]] (DATE), [[Asia and South Pacific Design Automation Conference]] (ASPDAC), and International Symposium on Quality Electronic Design (ISQED).
Over the past few years the conference location has been alternating among [[San Diego]], [[Austin]], [[Anaheim]], and [[San Francisco]]. The conference is usually held in June.
DAC is sponsored by several professional societies: ACM-SIGDA ([[Association for Computing Machinery]], [[Special Interest Group on Design Automation]]), ESD Alliance(Electronic System Design Alliance), and IEEE-CEDA ([[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]], [[IEEE Council on Electronic Design Automation]]), in technical cooperation with IEEE-SSCS ([[IEEE Solid-State Circuits Society]]). DAC is organized by hundreds of volunteer committee members from EDA companies and academia.<ref>http://www2.dac.com/committees.aspx.</ref>
